This report examines, for the Northern Triangle, (1) the extent to which U.S. agencies have established objectives for and delivered training to professionalize police, including promoting respect for human rights; (2) the extent to which agencies have collected data related to police training indicators; and (3) actions U.S. agencies have planned and undertaken to support the ability of partner nations to sustain police training. GAO reviewed government-wide and agency strategies, guidance documents, and project documents, and interviewed officials in Washington, D.C., and El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras. What GAO Found U.S. agencies have established few objectives to provide police training to police in El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras, but have not consistently incorporated respect for human rights in training delivered to police. For example, while U.S. national security strategies for El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras all include objectives to professionalize police, government-wide strategies and police assistance project documents include few objectives specifically to provide police training. Further, police assistance project documents also vary in the extent to which they include objectives or other internal control mechanisms to ensure human rights content is incorporated in police training. For example, while the Department of Defense (DOD) has not established specific objectives to train police on human rights, DOD officials told GAO that training delivered to police in El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras during fiscal years 2014 through 2017 included content on respect for human rights. Further, State has not established specific objectives or other internal control mechanisms to ensure that police training incorporates content promoting respect for human rights. For example, State officials told GAO that some INL-funded police training includes such content. Without such objectives or internal control mechanisms, it may be difficult for these agencies to account for the extent to which implementing partners include human rights content or to assess progress being made with respect to partner nation police forces' respect for human rights—a key goal of U.S. strategy in Central America. gao_GAO-18-45: Why GAO Did This Study Solid rocket motors (SRM) are the propulsion systems that propel various types of missiles and are also used in space launch activities, including the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's (NASA) Space Shuttle program. DOD relies on a multi-tiered supply chain to provide the SRMs that are used for missile propulsion. DOD reports that the SRM supplier base, including the sub-tier suppliers, is nearly identical across missile defense, tactical, and strategic missile systems that use SRMs. GAO was asked to review DOD's SRM supply chain. This report examines (1) trends in the SRM supply chain and the impact of these trends on the U.S. SRM supplier base, (2) the impact of these trends on the U.S. SRM supplier base, and (3) the extent to which manufacturing engineers' SRM design skills have declined since the missile program's inception. GAO reviewed DOD reports and DOD reports and interviewed DOD and industry officials. What GAO Found Over the last 20 years, the SRM industrial base has consolidated from six to two U.S. manufacturers—Aerojet Rocketdyne and Orbital ATK. Both manufacturers produce the small and large SRMs used in tactical and missile defense systems, and Orbital ATK also produces SRMs for strategic missiles. A senior DOD industrial base official told GAO that current DOD needs require two SRM manufacturers, but there is not enough demand to keep three companies economically viable. In DOD's industrial base reports to Congress, MIBP has reported that, while other industrial sectors are supported by commercial markets in addition to government needs, SRM manufacturers cater largely to the defense and space missions of the government and generally do not have a commercial base that can sustain production when the federal government's demand fluctuates. As a result, similar to the impact of NASA's retirement on the SRM supplier base, trends or decisions made in a particular program area can have broader effects and potentially result in cost increases for other programs. gao_GAO-18-453: Why GAO Did This Study Puget Sound is a large, complex, and potentially costly undertaking that involves many federal, state, local, tribal, and nongovernmental partners. GAO was asked to review Puget Sound restoration efforts. This report examines (1) Puget Sound restoration efforts and related expenditures for fiscal years 2012 through 2016; (2) how federal and nonfederal entities coordinate their restoration efforts and their views on this coordination; (3) the framework for assessing progress toward Puget Sound restoration; and (4) key factors, if any, federal and nonfederal entities identified that may limit the success of Puget Sound restoration. GAO surveyed 15 federal and 11 state entities and interviewed federal and nonfederal officials and representatives from conservation, agricultural, and fishing industry organizations. GAO also held six discussion groups with tribal and local representatives to obtain their views on factors that have helped and hindered their ability to implement restoration projects. What GAO Found Federal and state entities GAO surveyed identified numerous federal and state efforts that, in whole or in part, supported Puget Sound restoration from fiscal years 2012 through 2016. Some of these efforts focused exclusively on restoration activities in the Puget Sound basin, while others had a broader national, regional, or statewide focus or had a broader scope of work that did not center directly on restoration activities. These efforts were supported by a variety of federal and nonfederal funding sources, such as the Environmental Protection Agency's National Estuary Program and Puget Sound Geographic Program, which together expended about $142 million for activities in Puget Sound during this time frame according to EPA data. However, total expenditures across all restoration efforts are unknown, in part because of data limitations such as difficulties isolating expenditures specific to the Puget Sound basin for some efforts. Federal and nonfederal entities have established two primary interagency groups to coordinate Puget Sound restoration efforts at the strategic level and have identified both benefits and challenges to interagency coordination. The Puget Sound Management Conference, which started in 2007, and the Puget Sound Federal Task Force, which started in 2016, coordinate restoration efforts at the strategic level. The management conference focuses on issues surrounding Puget Sound restoration and tribal treaty rights. gao_GAO-18-669: Why GAO Did This Study The United States provides humanitarian assistance in countries that are often plagued by conflict, instability, or other issues that increase the risk of financial crimes. Some of these countries also face U.S. sanctions that are aimed at their governments or other actors that engage in terrorism or illicit activities. GAO was asked to review U.S. efforts to address banking access challenges encountered by nonprofit organizations (NPO). This report examines (1) the extent to which implementing partners of State and USAID experience banking access challenges that affect their implementation of humanitarian assistance projects, (2) USAID implementing partners' reporting on banking access challenges, and (3) actions relevant U.S. agencies have taken to help address banking access challenges encountered by NPOs. GAO reviewed relevant studies and USAID reports, and interviewed officials from Treasury, State, and USAID. What GAO Found For 7 of 18 selected U.S.-funded projects, the Department of State (State) and the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) had experienced banking access challenges that affected their implementation of humanitarian assistance projects. Most of the 18 partners GAO interviewed told GAO that they were able to mitigate these challenges through various actions or the challenges were not significant enough to affect project implementation. Nevertheless, a few partners noted that projects they were implementing were adversely affected by such challenges. For example, 1 of the 18 projects faced repeated delays as a result of banking access challenges. Additionally, 2 partners noted that they had to reduce the scope of implementation or suspend projects in their global humanitarian assistance portfolio because of banking access challenges. Furthermore, several partners and other NPOs told GAO that such challenges posed potential risks to project implementation. Lastly, a recent study found that more than two-thirds of all U.S.-based NPOs that work internationally experienced banking access challenges, but that few NPOs canceled programs as a result of those challenges. USAID generally does not require most partners to report in writing any challenges that do not affect implementation. Six of the 7 projects that noted experiencing banking access challenges were USAID projects. None of those 6 USAID partners reported on the banking access challenges they had experienced to USAID in their regular project reporting. gao_GAO-18-659: Why GAO Did This Study IRS's Office of Appeals is the only IRS unit with authority to consider settlements of tax controversies. Appeals is a separate unit within IRS and its chief reports directly to the Commissioner of Internal Revenue. GAO was asked to review IRS's appeals function. This report examines (1) the extent to which IRS has a standard process to resolve taxpayer appeals and (2) the extent to which Appeals measures its customer service and measures its performance. GAO analyzed IRS data on appeal cases closed from fiscal years 2014 through 2017, reviewed IRS documents, and interviewed IRS officials and external stakeholders. What GAO Found The Internal Revenue Service's (IRS) Office of Appeals (Appeals) has a standard process to resolve taxpayer appeals of IRS enforcement actions and decisions. Appeals is the only IRS unit with authority to consider settlements of tax controversies and has the primary responsibility to resolve these disputes without litigation to the maximum extent possible. Appeals has not conducted a skills gap analysis to help ensure it retains the necessary tax expertise to review appeals cases across multiple workstreams. Appeals has taken steps to mitigate the risk of having a sufficient number of staff with expertise in all areas of tax law. However, Appeals faces ongoing challenges in achieving its goal and may be unable to mitigate the risk of maintaining staff expertise. IRS does not monitor timeliness of transfers of all incoming appeal requests and Appeals does not communicate total resolution times to taxpayers. For appeal cases closed in fiscal year 2017, approximately 4 percent of collection appeals cases and nearly one quarter of examination appeal requests took more than 120 days to be transferred from IRS to Appeals. Delays in transferring appeals affect prompt resolution for the taxpayer and IRS. Additional monitoring of collection transfer time requirements together with establishing transfer time guidelines and procedures for examination appeal review could improve appeal review timeliness and overall taxpayer experience. Appeals measures its customer service standard internally, but does not make performance results available to taxpayers. Appeals conducts outreach at tax practitioner conferences to share information about its policy and procedures, but does not have a mechanism to solicit public input on policy changes. Appeals has taken steps to address practitioner reactions to operational changes underway. Appeals has acted to address practitioner reactions to operational changes underway. Developing a mechanism to leverage public input on future policy and procedure proposals would better position Appeals to bolster customer service and effectively implement changes
gao_GAO-19-200: Why GAO Did This Study The federal government provides E&T services to help individuals obtain and maintain jobs. gao_GAO-18-36: Why GAO Did This Study Improper payments are a significant problem in the federal government. gao_GAO-18-177: Why GAO Did This Study The FAA is responsible for providing air navigation services, including air traffic control across most of the United States, and is leading the Next Generation Air Transportation System (NextGen) effort. In 2007, DOD issued a memorandum directing DOD to equip military aircraft with ADS-B technology by January 1, 2020. Senate Report 114-255 included a provision that GAO assess issues related to the defense implications of implementation of NextGen. This report assesses the extent to which (1) DOD and FAA have identified security and operations risks and approved solutions to address these risks to military aircraft equipped with ADS-B Out technology; and (2) DOD has implemented key tasks in the 2007 Deputy Secretary of Defense memorandum on implementing NextGen. GAO reviewed relevant laws, guidance, and other documents; analyzed documents and interviewed officials from FAA, DOD, the military services, and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA); and visited multiple public websites. What GAO Found Since 2008, DOD and FAA have identified a variety of operations and physical security risks that could adversely affect military security and missions. These risks arise from information broadcast by ADS-B itself, as well as from potential ADS-B vulnerabilities to electronic warfare- and cyber-attacks, and from the potential divestment of secondary-surveillance radars. DOD and FAA have identified some potential mitigations for these risks, but the departments have not approved any solutions. For example, DOD and FAA have focused on equipping military aircraft with ADS-B technology and have not focused on solving or mitigating security risks from ADS-B. The approach being taken by FAA and DOD will not address key security risks that have been identified, and delays in producing an interagency agreement have significantly reduced the time available to implement any agreed-upon solutions before January 1, 2020, when the full deployment of ADS-B Out is required. Federal internal control standards state that federal agencies should make risk-based decisions in a timely manner. In the case of equipping military aircraft with ADS-B technology and addressing any risks associated with it, DOD and FAA have shared responsibility. gao_GAO-19-128: Why GAO Did This Study DOD is responsible for defending the U.S. homeland and interests from cyber attack, including those that occur in cyberspace and has developed capabilities for cyber operations. DOD has a long history of relying on IT systems to carry out its mission. However, DOD has not prioritized cybersecurity in weapon systems acquisitions. GAO was asked to review DOD's weapon systems cybersecurity. This report examines (1) factors that contribute to the current state of DOD weapon systems cybersecurity, and (2) steps DOD is taking to develop more cyber resilient weapon systems. GAO reviewed DOD policies and guidance, analyzed test reports, and interviewed DOD officials. What GAO Found Multiple factors contribute to the current state of the Department of Defense's (DOD) weapon systems cybersecurity, including: the increasingly computerized and networked nature of DOD weapons, DOD's past failure to prioritize weapon systems cybersecurity, and DOD's nascent understanding of how best to develop more cyber secure weapon systems. Specifically, DOD weapon systems are increasingly software and information technology dependent and more networked than ever before. This has transformed weapon capabilities and is a fundamental enabler of the United States' modern military capabilities. Yet this change has come at a cost. More weapon components can now be attacked using cyber capabilities. Furthermore, networks can be used as a pathway to attack other systems. GAO and others have warned of these risks for decades. Nevertheless, until recently, DOD did not prioritize cybersecurity in weapon systems acquisitions. In part because DOD historically focused on the cybersecurity of its networks but not weapon systems themselves, DOD is in the early stage of trying to understand how to apply cybersecurity to weapon systems. Several DOD officials explained that it will take some time, and possibly some missteps, for the department to learn what works and does not work with respect to weapon systems cybersecurity. GAO found that from 2012 to 2017, DOD testers routinely found mission-critical cyber vulnerabilities in nearly all weapon systems that were under development. Using relatively simple tools and techniques, testers were able to take control of these systems and largely operate undetected. In some cases, system operators were unable to effectively respond to the hacks. Furthermore, DOD does not know the full extent of its weapon system vulnerabilities because, for a number of reasons, tests were limited in scope and sophistication.

gao_GAO-19-159: Why GAO Did This Study In 2014, the abortion rate was 14.6 abortions per 1,000 women of reproductive age, according to a 2017 study. The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS), within the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), oversees Medicaid, which provides health care coverage to about a third of all U.S. women. GAO was asked to review issues related to abortion access in the Medicaid program. This report examines (1) factors that may present challenges to women accessing abortions, and (2) information on abortions eligible for federal Medicaid funding. GAO reviewed relevant literature and interviewed providers and selected providers in selected states, based on their abortion coverage and related payment requirements. GAO also surveyed all states, which are the largest beneficiaries of Medicaid, and reviewed CMS data on abortions eligible for federal Medicaid funding. What GAO Found GAO identified multiple factors that could present challenges to women accessing abortions, but the extent to which these factors were present in a state varied, as did their effect on access. For example, providers in some states said that they were able to cover the entire cost of the abortion and pay for associated costs, such as transportation, for women who could not afford to pay, while providers in other states said that they could not cover the entire cost of the abortion due to funding limitations. gao_GAO-19-21: Why GAO Did This Study The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) manages over 9,000 facilities, including about 6,000 facilities in the United States. gao_GAO-18-49: Why GAO Did This Study Contingent faculty—full-time and part-time faculty who do not have tenure or are not on the tenure track—are a key part of the instructional workforce at postsecondary institutions. gao_GAO-19-196: Why GAO Did This Study In 2017, Equifax, a large consumer reporting agency, breached its data and information systems. Equifax's breach highlighted the importance of protecting consumer information. GAO was asked to review the Equifax breach. This report examines (1) the federal laws and regulations governing consumer reporting agencies' (CRA) collection, use, and protection of consumer information; (2) measures the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has taken to enforce CRA compliance with requirements to protect consumer information; (3) measures the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) has taken to ensure that CRAs protect consumer information; and (4) FTC's and CFPB's roles in assisting consumers following a data breach and actions consumers can take following a data breach of a CRA. GAO reviewed relevant laws and regulations, and interviewed agency officials and representatives of industry, consumer, and privacy groups. What GAO Found The Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) governs the accuracy of consumer information and gives consumers rights to view, correct, or opt out of the sharing or use of certain aspects of their personal information among affiliates. CRAs also apply FCRA requirements to how they can use and share the information. For example, CRAs may share consumer information internally, but they limit the ability of affiliated companies to market products or services to consumers using shared consumer data. FTC enforces compliance with consumer protection laws under authorities provided in FCRA, the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act (GLBA), and the FTC Act. FTC has enforcement authority for nearly all companies not supervised by either a federal banking regulator or certain other federal agencies. GLBA authorizes FTC to issue certain rules and enforce compliance for all nonbank financial institutions and other entities not under the jurisdiction of a federal banking regulator, the National Credit Union Administration, Securities and Exchange Commission, or state insurance regulators. gao_GAO-18-457: Why GAO Did This Study In 2012, the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) adopted a rule requiring companies to disclose information about the sources of their conflict minerals. gao_GAO-18-696T: Why GAO Did This Study The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2008 directed the Departments of Veterans Affairs (VA) and Defense (DOD) to jointly develop and implement fully interoperable electronic health record systems or capabilities by September 30, 2009. This testimony discusses the extent to which the Interagency Program Office has functioned as the single point of accountability for VA and DOD's efforts to increase electronic health record interoperability and modernize their respective electronic health record systems. This statement is based on GAO reports issued from July 2008 through September 2017, selected updates conducted in February 2017, and selected updates conducted in June 2018. What GAO Found The Interagency Program Office has been involved in the various approaches taken by VA and DOD to increase health information interoperability and modernize their respective electronic health record systems. These approaches have included development of the Virtual Lifetime Electronic Record (VLER) and a new, common integrated electronic health record (iEHR) system. However, although the Interagency Program Office has led efforts to identify data standards that are critical to interoperability between systems, the office has not been effectively positioned to be the single point of accountability as called for in the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2008. Further, the future role of the Interagency Program Office with respect to VA's current electronic health record modernization program is uncertain.

gao_GAO-19-89: Why GAO Did This Study DOD is required to submit to Congress a biennial report providing information on its core depot maintenance capability requirements and workload. gao_GAO-19-24: Why GAO Did This Study The U.S. government has alleged that Agent Orange, a herbicide, was used in Vietnam during the Vietnam War and other locations in Southeast Asia. This report examines (1) the extent to which DOD procured, used, and destroyed Agent Orange; (2) the extent to which DOD developed a list of locations where herbicides, including Agent Orange, are thought to have been tested and stored outside of Vietnam; and (3) the challenges that DOD and VA face in detecting Agent Orange. What GAO Found The federal government maintains information on the procurement, use, and destruction of Agent Orange, and available records indicate that the Department of Defense (DOD) procured approximately 13.9 million gallons of the herbicide, which was either used in U.S. military operations in Southeast Asia, used for testing, or destroyed. GAO's analysis of available logbooks for 152 of the 158 shipments (approximately 96 percent) of Agent Orange to Southeast Asia that GAO identified indicates that the vessels carrying tactical herbicides generally stopped at foreign ports and sometimes at U.S. ports en route to Southeast Asia. gao_GAO-18-47: Why GAO Did This Study DOD supports the lead federal agency in the federal response to a major disaster or emergency. DOD's Section 1648 report, which was submitted in July 2016, included six statutorily required elements. GAO was asked to review DOD's Section 1648 report. This report examines the extent to which DOD's Section 1648 report addressed the statutorily required elements. GAO analyzed DOD's Section 1648 report and interviewed relevant officials. What GAO Found The Department of Defense's (DOD) Section 1648 report addressed some, but not all, six statutorily required elements. DOD did not develop a comprehensive plan; instead, the department submitted a collection of separate documents that addressed some, but not all six statutorily required elements (hereafter referred to as DOD's Section 1648 report). DOD officials agreed that their submission was not a comprehensive plan. gao_GAO-18-574: Why GAO Did This Study The MHS is responsible for providing health care to beneficiaries in the United States. The NDAA 2016 directed the MHS to align its quality measures for direct and purchased care. GAO was asked to review the MHS's quality measures. This report examines the extent to which the MHS (1) uses a common set of quality measures for direct and purchased care, and (2) has established performance standards and related corrective action requirements for individual providers in direct and purchased care. GAO reviewed DOD documents and interviewed officials from DOD, the MHS, and the private health insurers that administer the MHS's networks of civilian providers for purchased care. What GAO Found The Department of Defense's (DOD) Military Health Service (MHS) does not use a common set of quality measures on its Core and Purchased Care Dashboards to assess the quality of care provided through direct and purchased care. The MHS uses 43 measures on its Core Dashboard and 18 measures on its Purchased Care Dashboard to assess the quality of care delivered in direct care and 18 measures on its Purchased Care Dashboard. The MHS uses these measures to assess the quality of care delivered in direct care only, and it does not use a common set of measures for purchased care. For both direct and purchased care, the MHS uses measures on its Dashboards that assess a more limited range of quality areas and medical conditions as compared to the widely used quality measure sets adopted by Medicare and private health insurers. Without using a broader range of available quality measures available—measures that many purchased care providers already report to CMS and private health insurers—DOD is missing an opportunity to better target the most critical quality of care issues in the MHS. The MHS has established performance standards in direct care related to the Core Dashboard measures and has corrective action requirements for MTFs that do not meet the standards. However, the MHS has not established performance standards related to the Purchased Care Dashboard measures for individual civilian providers in purchased care and therefore does not have related corrective action requirements for these providers. The MHS has established performance standards in direct care related to the Core Dashboard measures and has corrective action requirements for MTFs that do not meet the standards. However, the MHS has not established performance standards related to the Purchased Care Dashboard measures for individual civilian providers in purchased care and therefore does not have related corrective action requirements for these providers.

gao_GAO-19-87: Why GAO Did This Study Tribal governments are recognized as distinct, independent political communities that are part of the unique political structure of layered sovereigns and internal governments that comprise the U.S. system of government. gao_GAO-18-415: Why GAO Did This Study The United States entered into a compact of free association with the Federated States of Micronesia (FSM) and the Republic of the Marshall Islands (RMI) in 1986. The compact provided a framework for the United States and the two countries to work toward achieving economic development and self-sufficiency. The amended compacts' implementing legislation authorized and appropriated direct financial assistance to the FSM and RMI in fiscal years 2004 through 2023, with the base amounts decreasing in most years. The annual decrements in assistance are added to the amounts deposited in the trust funds established under the amended compacts for the two nations. Earnings from the compact trust funds are intended to provide an annual source of revenue after the scheduled end of compact sector grants at the end of fiscal year 2023. GAO was asked to review issues related to the FSM and RMI transition from compact grant assistance to relying on income from the compact trust funds. This report examines (1) the use and role of federal funds and programs in the FSM and RMI budgets, (2) projected compact trust fund disbursements and potential strategies to address risks to those disbursements, and (3) FSM and RMI efforts to prepare for the scheduled decrements in compact grant funding and the transition to relying on compact trust fund income. GAO analyzed U.S. law, the amended compacts' implementing legislation, and the trust fund agreements with each country. GAO also interviewed U.S., FSM, and RMI officials. What GAO Found The FSM and RMI continue to rely on U.S. grants and programs that end in 2023. Compact sector grants and the SEG, each of which end in 2023, continue to support a substantial portion of government expenditures in the FSM and RMI. gao_GAO-18-456: Why GAO Did This Study NNSA and DOD are managing four ongoing LEPs to consolidate the nuclear bomb stockpile into fewer weapon types. This report examines (1) the extent to which NNSA and DOD have incorporated best practices in developing the B61-12 LEP cost estimate, (2) the extent to which NNSA and DOD have identified and are managing risks within the program, and (3) the extent to which NNSA and DOD have identified and are managing risks within the program's responsibility. GAO analyzed program documents and interviewed program officials. What GAO Found The National Nuclear Security Administration (NNSA) substantially incorporated most of the cost estimating best practices identified by GAO's past work when it developed the $7.6 billion program cost estimate for the B61-12 life extension program (LEP). GAO's cost estimating guide identifies four characteristics of such an estimate: it is comprehensive, well-documented, accurate, and credible. The program substantially met the criteria for a comprehensive cost estimate, which GAO believes contributed to the program's estimate being reliable. The program used different methods and assumptions about future program performance, which led to differences between the estimates. For example, the program estimated that the program would cost $7.6 billion and that the LEP would be completed in fiscal year 2025, with a first production unit date of March 2020. However, NNSA did not document the rationale for its decision to use the program office's lower estimate unchanged or a plan for how it would take the independent cost estimate into consideration. GAO recommended in a January 2018 report that NNSA should document and justify key decisions based on a reconciliation of LEP cost estimates with the Office of Cost Estimating and Program Evaluation's independent cost estimates. NNSA agreed with this recommendation. The program also used different methods and assumptions about future program performance, which led to differences between the estimates. For example, the program estimated that the program would cost approximately $10.0 billion and take about 2 years longer than the independent cost estimate. However, NNSA did not document the rationale for its decision to use the program office's lower estimate unchanged or a plan for how it would take the independent cost estimate into consideration.

gao_GAO-18-445: Why GAO Did This Study NIST provides measurement services and supports documentary standards development. NIST's efforts help ensure U.S. industry's ability to develop and use standards to enhance the economic and technological competitiveness of the United States. GAO was asked to review NIST's efforts to develop and use standards. This report examines (1) challenges NIST faces in providing measurement services and supporting documentary standards development, and (2) steps NIST has taken to address these challenges. GAO reviewed relevant literature and interviewed NIST officials and stakeholders, including industry and government officials, standards executives, and others. GAO also conducted five focus groups with stakeholders from five different industries and five different government agencies. What GAO Found The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) faces challenges in providing measurement services and supporting documentary standards development, based on GAO's literature review, NIST stakeholder focus groups, and interviews with stakeholders and agency officials. First, the breadth of U.S. industry and the number of stakeholder development organizations (SDO) make it challenging to identify and prioritize among these needs. Second, ensuring adequate U.S. representation in international standards activities can be challenging due to the number of activities and other factors. Third, the involvement of multiple federal agencies and interdisciplinary issues makes coordinating among federal agencies on documentary standards challenging. NIST works to address the challenges it faces in providing measurement services and supporting documentary standards development in a variety of ways, but opportunities exist to improve some efforts. First, NIST's efforts help address challenges to identifying and prioritizing measurement-service and documentary-standards needs, but some efforts do not fully align with federal guidance or NIST policy. Second, NIST's efforts help support U.S. representation in international standards organizations but may not fully implement its role and address the challenge it faces. Third, NIST's efforts support federal agency coordination on standards issues but do not fully align with selected leading collaboration practices. For example, NIST has not updated its charter to reflect recent changes in documentary standards. Without a mechanism to identify and respond to circumstances when U.S. representation may be inadequate, NIST may miss opportunities to take action in furtherance of its mission to support U.S. competitiveness by helping to ensure adequate U.S. representation in international standards activities.

gao_GAO-18-189T: Why GAO Did This Study The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) is responsible for providing health care to veterans. In fiscal year 2015, VA obligated about $10.1 billion to purchase care from non-VA providers. In 2005, Congress enacted a round of closures and realignments of military installations to reduce excess infrastructure and produce savings. This testimony discusses (1) VA's efforts to align its facilities and services and (2) key elements and challenges affecting DOD and the BRAC Commission in 2005. This statement is based on GAO's April 2017 report, VA Integrated Planning: Limitations in VA's Capital Planning Process Impede its Alignment of Facilities (GAO-17-23). GAO reviewed relevant laws, regulations, and guidance; interviewed officials from DOD, the military services, and the BRAC Commission; and reviewed relevant documents and interviewed officials from the military services and the BRAC Commission. What GAO Found Geographic shifts in the veterans' population, changes in health care delivery, an aging infrastructure, and limited stakeholder involvement affect VA's efforts to align its services and real property portfolio to meet the needs of veterans. For example, there has been a shift over time from inpatient to outpatient care. This shift will likely result in underutilized space once used for inpatient care. In such instances, it is often difficult and costly for VA to modernize, renovate, and retrofit these older facilities. In June 2017, VA reported that its facility inventory includes 430 vacant or mostly vacant buildings that are, on average, more than 60 years old, and an additional 784 buildings that are underutilized. The historic status of some VA facilities adds to the complexity of converting or disposing of them. In some instances, it may be more expensive to renovate than to demolish and rebuild outdated facilities. In other cases, however, there may not be an option to demolish if these buildings are designated as historic. VA has also encountered challenges to its facility alignment efforts, in part, because it has not consistently followed best practices for effectively engaging stakeholders. VA may align its facilities to meet veterans' needs by expanding or consolidating facilities or services. Stakeholders—including veterans, local, state, and federal officials; Veterans Service Organizations; historic preservation groups; VA staff; and Congress—sometimes view changes as working against their interests or those of their constituents, especially when services are eliminated

gao_GAO-19-209: Why GAO Did This Study DOD acquires new weapons for its warfighters through a management process known as the defense acquisition process. This process has multiple phases, including (1) technology maturation and risk reduction, (2) engineering and manufacturing development, and (3) production and deployment. GAO was asked to review DOD's acquisition programs. This report examines (1) factors that influence the workforce size, composition, and mix of selected DOD acquisition programs and (2) the personnel costs for selected DOD acquisition programs. GAO reviewed DOD's budget requests for fiscal years 2018 and 2019 associated with the 11 selected programs and interviewed DOD officials. What GAO Found Several interrelated factors influenced the workforce size, composition, and mix of the 11 selected major defense acquisition programs GAO reviewed. First, the program assumed responsibility for technical development and integration, as well as the program's stage within the acquisition life cycle. Second, the program workforce mix varied depending on the use of contractor personnel, which was based on the workload requirements and the availability of government personnel to provide the skills needed. Programs were generally structured as either stand-alone--new, high priority, complex weapon system platforms with dedicated personnel--or as part of a portfolio of related programs to share personnel across programs. The personnel costs for each major defense acquisition program GAO reviewed are included in different parts of the President's annual budget request, including budget justification documents, but are not always clearly identifiable due to different approaches used to report such costs. The DOD Financial Management Regulation gives the military departments flexibility in how they submit program personnel costs. For example, it suggests the use of "typical" personnel cost categories for research, development, test, and evaluation programs to include in their individual program budget exhibits, but it also allows the departments to use the personnel cost categories they deem to be the most appropriate when formulating the budget request. In reviewing DOD's budget requests for fiscal years 2018 and 2019, GAO found that personnel costs are budgeted for in two main wayscentrally by the military department, or by an individual programdepending on whether the requests are for military, civilian, or contractor support services. Personnel costs that are program-funded are included in individual program budget justification requests, whereas personnel costs that are centrally funded by the military departments are aggregated into one or more line items in the military department's specific appropriation request.

gao_GAO-18-297: Why GAO Did This Study Home equity is the principal asset that a homeowner can build in his or her home. The federal government provides a variety of programs and products that can help build home equity, including mortgage guarantees and insurance, down-payment assistance, and direct loans. GAO was asked to review the federal government's role in accelerating home equity building. This report describes (1) how federal homeownership assistance programs affect home equity building, and (2) options, including private-sector mortgage products, through which borrowers can accelerate home equity building and the trade-offs of these options for both borrowers and lenders. GAO reviewed relevant federal statutes, regulations, and agency program policies and guidance; analyzed relevant academic papers and literature; and interviewed agency officials and stakeholders, including academics, industry stakeholders, and others. What GAO Found Existing federal homeownership assistance programs use features and mechanisms that can have equity-building effects, but the programs are not specifically designed to accelerate equity building. The programs can assist homeowners to build equity over time by providing access to homeownership, but the programs do not have an explicit focus on accelerating the ongoing pace of paying down the loan principal faster than a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage. Rather, the overall focus of the programs is on providing affordable access to homeownership, according to officials of relevant agencies and entities and based on their mission goals. For example, the goal of the Federal Housing Administration's mortgage insurance program is to facilitate access to affordable mortgages for home buyers who might not otherwise be served by the private market. Federal and federally mandated programs that provide funding for grants and loans for down-payment assistance can have equity-building effects. For example, the Department of Housing and Urban Development's (HUD) HOME Investment Partnership Program provides funding to states and localities to be used exclusively for affordable housing activities to benefit low-income households. HUD's Rural Housing Service and the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) insure mortgages for home purchases, repair, and rental housing development. Federal direct loans can provide access to homeownership. For example, the Department of Veterans Affairs' Rural Housing Service and VA provide direct loans to eligible Native American veterans to finance the purchase, construction, or improvement of homes on federal trust land. Borrowers have options to accelerate equity building that include obtaining shorter-term mortgages, making more frequent or additional payments, or choosing a mortgage product available in the private mortgage market

gao_GAO-19-229: Why GAO Did This Study The Navy has 51 attack submarines, and the Navy expects to spend approximately $266 million in fiscal year 2018 constant dollars on these submarines. GAO also visited three of the four public shipyards that conduct attack submarine repair work, and interviewed officials about challenges affecting operational efficiency and performance. What GAO Found The Navy has been unable to begin or complete the vast majority of its attack submarine maintenance periods on time resulting in significant maintenance delays and operating and support cost expenditures. GAO's analysis of Navy maintenance data shows that between fiscal year 2008 and the end of fiscal year 2018, attack submarines will have incurred 10,363 days of idle time and maintenance delays as a result of delays in getting into and out of the shipyards. GAO's analysis found that the primary driver affecting attack submarines are delays in completing depot maintenance. For example, of the 10,363 total days of lost time since fiscal year 2008, 8,472 (82 percent) were due to depot maintenance delays. GAO also found that the Navy incurs significant costs in operating and supporting submarines that are experiencing maintenance delays and idle time. GAO analyzed the operating and support costs the Navy incurs on average to estimate the costs of crewing, maintaining, and supporting attack submarines that are delayed in getting into and out of the shipyards. While acknowledging the magnitude of these costs, Navy officials stated that there may be some benefits that could be realized from these operating and support costs since crews on idle attack submarines can conduct some limited training. The Navy has begun to address some challenges associated with attack submarine maintenance delays, but it has not effectively allocated maintenance periods to limit idle time and maintenance delays. For example, the Navy has hired a new workforce to address workforce shortages and facilities needs at the public shipyards. gao_GAO-19-230: Why GAO Did This Study Identity theft occurs when individuals' information is used without authorization in an attempt to commit fraud or other crimes. gao_GAO-18-679: Why GAO Did This Study TCS programs provide scholarships to students who meet certain income and other criteria. This report examines (1) how TCS program donations determine student eligibility and consider other factors when determining scholarship award amounts, and (2) the extent to which TCS program donations affect the amount that donors owe in state and federal taxes. What GAO Found The 22 state TCS programs often determine student eligibility for scholarships based on household income and use a range of factors to determine scholarship award amounts. Seventeen of the 22 programs have income limits (i.e., the maximum amount of household income a student can have and still be eligible for a scholarship). Eleven of the 22 programs allow eligible donors (either individuals, businesses, or both) to claim 100 percent of their donations as state tax credits, meaning that, for each dollar donated, the amount of state taxes owed (i.e., the donor's tax liability) is reduced by a dollar, up to any maximum donation limits set by the program. The other 11 programs offer tax credits of 50 percent to 85 percent of donations. All but one of the programs prohibits donors from receiving a tax credit greater than their tax liability in a given year, although two thirds of the programs allow donors to carry forward portions of the credits to use in future years. gao_GAO-18-34: Why GAO Did This Study VA operates one of the largest health care systems in the country, providing care to about 7 million veterans. In 2016, VA began a transition to MSPV-NG, a new program that limits the range of items medical centers can purchase. GAO was asked to review VA's transition to MSPV-NG. This report addresses the extent to which (1) VA's implementation of MSPV-NG was effective in meeting program goals, and (2) VA has awarded contracts on an emergency basis for routine supplies and ongoing services, and what impact, if any, these awards have on VA's acquisition function. GAO reviewed VA policies and guidance, analyzed VA data, and interviewed VA officials and supply chain managers from four hospital networks. What GAO Found The Department of Veterans Affairs' (VA) implementation of the Medical Surgical Prime Vendor-Next Generation (MSPV-NG) program—from its initial work to identify a list of supply requirements in 2015, through its roll-out of the formulary to medical centers in December 2016—was not executed in line with leading practices. Specifically, VA lacked a documented program strategy, leadership stability, and workforce capacity for the transition that—if in place—could have facilitated buy-in for the change throughout the organization. Furthermore, the initial requirements development process and tight time frames contributed to ineffective contracting processes. As a result, VA developed an initial formulary that did not meet the needs of the medical centers. VA made some changes in the second phase of requirements development to address deficiencies identified in the initial roll out, namely by increasing the level of clinical involvement. However, VHA has not yet achieved its goals for utilization and cost avoidance. VA designated a substantial number of its procurements in fiscal year 2016 as emergencies, and GAO found that it frequently uses emergency procurements to buy routine supplies and ongoing services that do not warrant the emergency designation defined in VHA guidance. Among the 18 contract actions GAO reviewed from three Veterans Integrated Service Networks, GAO found instances of emergency procurements caused by shortcomings in planning, funding, and communication. These emergency procurements strain the capacity of VA's acquisition workforce and put the government at risk of paying more than it should for goods and services. Among the 18 contract actions GAO reviewed, GAO found instances of emergency procurements caused by shortcomings in planning, funding, and communication.
gao_GAO-19-219: Why GAO Did This Study In fiscal year 2018, the MEP program provided financial assistance to 51 MEP centers, which provide services to manufacturers. In fiscal year 2017, the AICA cost share adjustment was enacted to increase federal assistance to MEP centers and to reset the cost share to 1:1. The AICA included a provision for GAO to review the AICA cost share adjustment. This report describes (1) MEP centers' views regarding the extent to which the AICA cost share adjustment has helped them serve manufacturers and (2) the extent to which NIST data show impacts of the cost share adjustment on centers' finances and activities. GAO surveyed all 51 MEP centers and received a response from every center. GAO also interviewed officials from nine MEP centers, selected based on factors such as the number of manufacturers in the state, and whether the center is operated by a nonprofit, state agency, or university. What GAO Found In response to GAO's survey, most Manufacturing Extension Partnership (MEP) centers reported that the 2017 American Innovation and Competitiveness Act (AICA) cost share adjustment has helped them serve manufacturers, but some center officials indicated that the impact is hard to measure. Specifically, most MEP centers GAO surveyed reported that the AICA's adjustment of the cost share to 1:1 for the life of a center's cooperative agreement has increased their financial stability and helped them serve very small and rural manufacturers. According to the survey results, centers run by nonprofit organizations reported greater impacts of the cost share adjustment than those run by states or universities. In follow-up interviews, some MEP center officials indicated that the impact is difficult to measure because of other recent changes that have also impacted their ability to serve manufacturers. NIST data show that there have been some changes in MEP centers' finances and activities since the 2017 AICA cost share adjustment. However, these changes generally began around the time NIST recompeted the centers' cooperative agreements, before the enactment of the AICA, and cannot necessarily be linked to the cost share adjustment. NIST data show that the total number of manufacturers MEP centers reported serving increased from approximately 8,000 to 8,400, very small manufacturers MEP centers reported serving increased from approximately 2,600 to 2,700, and rural manufacturers MEP centers reported serving increased from approximately 1,500 to 1,600. NIST officials said that a longer time span would be needed to identify trends in the manufacturers served by MEP centers
gao_GAO-19-94: Why GAO Did This Study OMB and GSA have been involved in shared services reform efforts for decades. OMB and GSA have been involved in shared services reform efforts for decades. GAO was asked to review the federal government's efforts to promote shared services. This report (1) identifies the progress and challenges associated with federal shared services initiatives for selected human resources (HR) and financial management activities, and (2) assesses OMB and GSA's actions to address those challenges. GAO reviewed relevant reports and OMB and GSA documents and interviewed officials from OMB and GSA, the agencies that oversee shared services policy and guidance, and the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) and the Office of Financial Innovation and Transformation (FIT). GAO also reviewed OMB and GSA's efforts to identify and address challenges and lessons learned from past migrations. What GAO Found OMB's efforts to promote HR shared services resulted in cost savings, cost avoidance, and more consistent service delivery. OMB announced the HR Line of Business in 2004 simultaneously with the Financial Management Line of Business. These shared services initiatives shared similar goals: (1) standardize systems, business processes, and data elements to promote consistency across the federal government; and (2) reduce costs by establishing a marketplace or a system of buying and selling products and services. OMB designated FIT as managing partner of the Financial Management Line of Business and designated four FSSPs to provide financial management services to other agencies. FIT also worked with the Chief Human Capital Officers community to develop more than 40 business use cases for financial management activities. FIT officials estimated these projects could contribute to cost savings of around $620 million over 5 years, but they did not track cost savings. Wider adoption of HR and financial management shared services has been impeded by challenges in two areas. First, shared services efforts have faced persistent governance challenges, such as limited interagency collaboration, difficulty reconciling benefits and trade-offs, and limited oversight and technical support for shared services migrations. Second, the efforts have also experienced marketplace challenges, which involve difficulty obtaining funding to invest in shared services, demand uncertainty among providers, and limited choices for customers. These issues hampered efforts to establish effective and efficient shared services marketplaces. As a result, these marketplaces have not been able to consistently support sufficient competition limiting the potential cost sharing efficiencies and improved performance that could be realized with greater usage.

gao_GAO-18-198: Why GAO Did This Study Wireless networks are vital to the nation's communications infrastructure, but they also face physical risks, such as natural disasters and other emergencies. FCC regulates wireless networks and carriers, and FCC has reported that the loss of backhaul service is a major cause of a cell site's unavailability. GAO was asked to review wireless network resiliency since 2013. This report examines (1) trends in wireless outages attributed to physical incidents since 2009 as reported to FCC, (2) actions federal agencies and industry have taken since 2013 to improve wireless network resiliency, and (3) options that federal agencies could take to improve network resiliency and their advantages and disadvantages. GAO analyzed FCC data on wireless outages from 2009 through 2016, reviewed relevant literature, and interviewed FCC and DHS officials and industry stakeholders. What GAO Found The number of wireless outages attributed to a physical incident increased from 2009 to 2016, and outages due to natural disasters lasted longest trends in number and reported causes of wireless outages. Specifically, the number of outages with a physical incident reported as a root cause increased from 189 outages in 2009 to 1,079 in 2016. The number of outages increased substantially during the first few years of this period and then was relatively stable, which mirrored the trend for all wireless outages. According to FCC officials, the increase in reported outages was due to increases in both the number of wireless customers and wireless infrastructure over this period, as well as due to FCC's outreach to wireless companies to clarify the thresholds for which carriers are required to report wireless outages to help ensure that carriers were consistently and fully reporting outages. From 2009 to 2016, about one-third of all wireless outages reported to FCC (6,002 of 18,325) were attributed to physical incidents. Of wireless outages attributed to physical incidents, most were due to accidents, such as cable damage due to a backhoe cut, which was the root cause for 74 percent of wireless outages attributed to a physical incident. Natural disasters—including tornados and wildfires—were the root cause for 25 percent of wireless outages attributed to a physical incident. gao_GAO-18-97: Why GAO Did This Study Grade crossing collisions are one of the leading causes of fatalities in the railroad industry. gao_GAO-18-477: Why GAO Did This Study The United States has a 90-day obligation to hold the equivalent of net imports of crude oil and petroleum products. The United States also has a 90-day obligation to release reserves in the event of a collective action to respond to a supply disruption. GAO was asked to review the SPR. This report examines (1) how the United States and other IEA members meet their obligations and hold significant proportions of their reserves as petroleum products rather than as crude oil, and (2) the extent to which DOE has identified the optimal size for the SPR or the potential need for additional regional product reserves. GAO analyzed IEA data on member reserves as of December 2017, reviewed DOE's 2016 long-term strategic review of the SPR, and interviewed agency officials and experts. What GAO Found In terms of how the United States and other IEA members meet their obligations, most other IEA members differ from the United States in two basic ways. Specifically, as of December 2017, most IEA members rely at least in part on private rather than public reserves to meet their obligations, and most hold significant proportions of their reserves as petroleum products rather than as crude oil. Unlike the United States, most IEA members hold at least a third of their reserves as petroleum products rather than as crude oil. In contrast, more than 99 percent of the SPR (665.5 million barrels as of March 2018) is held as crude oil, all of which is stored at the four storage sites in Louisiana and Texas. While DOE has examined a range of sizes for the SPR, it has not identified the optimal size for the SPR to meet U.S. energy security needs and IEA obligations, and DOE's analysis of SPR sizes was limited in three ways. gao_GAO-18-483: Why GAO Did This Study Puerto Rico is the most populous U.S. territory with approximately 3.3 million residents. Puerto Rico and its residents are generally subject to the same federal laws as the states and their residents, except in cases where specific exemptions have been made, such as with certain federal programs. In May 2016, DOL published a final rule that would increase the salary level threshold for exempt employees from overtime pay. GAO was asked to review the economic conditions in Puerto Rico. This report examines (1) the economic conditions in Puerto Rico as of the end of 2016; and (2) the potential effects of implementing the 2016 Overtime Rule on Puerto Rico's economy. GAO analyzed Puerto Rico's economic data from 1990 through 2016 and passenger data for Puerto Rican airports for years 2016 and 2017; reviewed relevant federal laws, regulations, and agency guidance; and interviewed agency officials and experts. What GAO Found Puerto Rico's economic condition is difficult to evaluate prior to Hurricane Maria, which devastated Puerto Rico and left nearly all its residents without potable running water and electricity. In addition, the existing infrastructure for cellular and wireless service was rendered virtually useless, hampering communication. Four months after Hurricane Maria, more than a third of Puerto Rico's energy customers remained without power. The lack of power and communication impeded residents' ability to return to work. According to the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), rebuilding will take years. The Puerto Rico Oversight, Management, and Economic Stability Act (PROMESA) established a Financial Oversight and Management Board for Puerto Rico (Oversight Board), and granted it broad powers of fiscal and budgetary control over Puerto Rico. The Overtime Rule was enacted in May 2016 and was intended to increase the salary level threshold for exempt employees from overtime pay. The 2016 Overtime Rule would have applied to Puerto Rico; however, on June 30, 2016, prior to the rule's effective date of December 1, 2016, PROMESA was enacted which, in part, delayed the applicability of this rule to Puerto Rico. In the interim, the 2004 Overtime Rule salary level threshold for exempt employees of $23,660 remained in effect. gao_GAO-18-559: Why GAO Did This Study In 2017, Equifax, a company that assembles and evaluates consumer credit information, was breached by hackers. The breach affected 143 million U.S. consumers. GAO was asked to review the breach. This report (1) summarizes the events regarding the breach and the steps taken by the company to assess, respond to, and recover from the incident and (2) describes the actions that federal customers and oversight agencies took in response to the breach. GAO reviewed relevant federal laws and regulations, and interviewed agency officials. What GAO Found In March 2017, unidentified individuals discovered a known vulnerability in software running on Equifax's online dispute portal that could be used to obtain access to the system. In May of that year, attackers exploited the vulnerability and began to extract data containing personally identifiable information (PII) from Equifax's information systems. According to Equifax, the attackers used a number of techniques to disguise their exploit of the Equifax systems and the database queries they conducted. On July 29, 2017, Equifax discovered the breach and reported that it took actions to address the factors that allowed the attackers to successfully gain access to its network. Further, the company reported that it took steps to identify, notify, and provide support to individuals who were potentially impacted by the breach. After the breach, federal customer agencies took a variety of actions based on their responsibilities and how the breach affected their operations. Specifically, the agencies that were customers of the company's services conducted independent assessments of the company's security controls, revised their own identity proofing processes, and made changes to their contracts with Equifax, among other activities. Equifax did not ask the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), which is the central agency that responds to cyber incidents across the federal government, to assist in responding to the breach. Nevertheless, the department took the step of reminding federal agencies of the importance of correcting the software vulnerability that led to the breach. In addition, the oversight agencies, the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection (BCFP), and the Federal Trade Commission (FTC), began taking actions to investigate the breach and inform the public.
gao_GAO-19-136: Why GAO Did This Study DOD space systems are critical to the nation's security and economy. DOD has struggled to deliver software-intensive systems that meet operational requirements within expected time frames. GAO was asked to review software-intensive DOD space systems. This report addresses, for selected software-intensive programs, (1) the extent to which these programs have involved users and delivered software using newer development approaches; and (2) what software-specific management challenges, if any, these programs have faced. GAO reviewed relevant DOD policies, guidance, and other documents; analyzed software development documentation; and interviewed DOD officials and contractors. What GAO Found The Department of Defense (DOD) has struggled to deliver software-intensive space programs that meet operational requirements within expected time frames. Although user involvement is critical to the success of any software development effort, key programs often did not effectively involve users early or continually during development, base user feedback on actual working software, or incorporate user feedback into subsequent software deliveries. Most programs had plans to incorporate these elements of user engagement throughout their software development efforts, but they often did not follow those plans due, in part, to the lack of specific guidance on user involvement and feedback. Regarding frequency of software delivery, while DODI 5000.02 suggests that programs deliver incremental software deliveries every 1 to 2 years, the programs GAO reviewed often continued to deliver software consistent with the long delivery schedules common to waterfall development. DOD is taking steps to address this issue. Selected programs have had software-specific management challenges, but DOD is taking steps to address them. For example, three of the programs GAO reviewed had difficulty integrating and maintaining modified commercial software during development. gao_GAO-18-658: Why GAO Did This Study VA's health care system is a complex system of health care providers and pharmacies that provide health care services to veterans and their families. VA's health care system is organized into entities at the headquarters, regional, and local levels. VA's pharmacy system is responsible for supporting VAMCs with a broad range of pharmacy services, such as promoting appropriate drug therapy, ensuring medication safety, providing clinical guidance to pharmacists and other clinicians, and maintaining VA's formulary of medications and supplies VAMCs use to deliver pharmacy benefits. GAO was asked to review VAMC pharmacy inventory management. This report examines (1) the approaches VAMCs have taken to manage their pharmacy inventories and (2) the extent to which VA's oversight of VAMC pharmacy inventory management is limited. GAO reviewed VA policies and procedures, interviewed VA officials, and visited five VAMCs selected based on geographic location and pharmacy inventory management. What GAO Found The Department of Veterans Affairs' (VA) five VAMCs GAO reviewed have generally similar approaches for managing their pharmacy inventories, with some unique approaches in implementing two steps of the pharmacy inventory management process: procuring medications from vendors or other suppliers, receiving and storing these medications, tracking medications to account for all items and prevent diversion, dispensing medications to patients, and disposing of expired medications. GAO found that while the five selected VAMCs have similar approaches for receiving and storing, dispensing, and disposing of medications, some VAMCs have also taken unique approaches in implementing two steps of the pharmacy inventory management process: procurement and tracking. VA policy outlines parameters for VAMCs to manage their pharmacy inventories, and VA officials told GAO that VAMC pharmacy staff can use discretion to implement their own approaches for managing their pharmacy inventories. VA does not yet have a VA-wide pharmacy inventory management system in place that would allow it to monitor VAMC pharmacy inventory in real time and provide better oversight of how VAMC pharmacies manage their inventories. gao_GAO-18-106: Why GAO Did This Study CSPF is one of the largest multiemployer pension plans in the United States. In 1982, CSPF was subject to a federal court-enforceable consent decree that gave CSPF the authority to set and change its investment policy and to set and execute its investment returns. GAO was asked to review CSPF. This report examines (1) what is known about the factors that contributed to CSPF's critical financial condition; (2) what has been CSPF's investment policy, and the process for setting and executing it, since the consent decree was established; and (3) how CSPF performed over time, particularly compared to similar pension plans. GAO reviewed relevant federal laws and regulations, literature, and documentation, and interviewed federal agency officials and other stakeholders. What GAO Found The Central States, Southeast and Southwest Areas Pension Fund (CSPF) has been underfunded since the consent decree was established in 1982. CSPF's unfunded liability increased by approximately $11.2 billion (in inflation-adjusted dollars) between January 1983 and January 2016. As a consequence, participant benefits were never fully secured by plan assets over this period, as measured by the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA). Stakeholders identified several factors that contributed to CSPF's critical financial condition and reflect the challenges faced by many multiemployer plans. For example, many multiemployer plans have experienced financial difficulties due to a combination of investment losses and insufficient employer contributions. In addition to being underfunded prior to the consent decree going into effect, stakeholders identified other specific factors that contributed to CSPF's critical financial condition, such as trends within the national trucking industry and its workforce, funding challenges and common investment practices of multiemployer plans, and the impact of market downturns on long-term investment performance. Stakeholders also described the effects of the 2007 withdrawal of a key employer, United Parcel Service (UPS), on CSPF's critical financial condition. CSPF's investment policy has generally increased its allocation to equities, but shifted toward fixed income in 2017, ahead of projected insolvency. gao_GAO-18-630: Why GAO Did This Study FCC collects and uses data that capture broadband availability to measure broadband access on tribal lands, leading to overstatements of broadband access on tribal lands. FCC has identified increasing access to affordable broadband as a long-term strategic goal. In 2018, Congress directed FCC to develop a report evaluating broadband coverage in certain tribal lands and to complete a proceeding to address unserved areas by September 23, 2020. FCC collects and uses data that capture broadband availability to measure broadband access on tribal lands, leading to overstatements of broadband access on tribal lands. GAO was asked to review FCC's approach to collecting broadband availability data. This report discusses the extent to which (1) FCC's approach to collecting broadband availability data accurately captures the ability of Americans living on tribal lands to access broadband Internet services and (2) FCC obtains tribal input on the accuracy of provider-submitted broadband data for tribal lands. GAO analyzed FCC's data and FCC's guidance and documents, and interviewed FCC officials and industry stakeholders. What GAO Found The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) collects and uses data that capture broadband availability to measure broadband access on tribal lands, leading to overstatements of broadband access on tribal lands. FCC's method of collecting mobile and fixed broadband data from providers (the Form 477) does not accurately or completely capture broadband access on tribal lands because it (1) captures nationwide broadband availability data—areas where providers may have broadband infrastructure—but does so in a way that leads to overstatements of availability, and (2) does not capture information on factors that FCC and tribal stakeholders have stated can affect broadband access on tribal lands, such as affordability, service quality, and denials of service. Nonetheless, FCC uses its Form 477 broadband availability data in annual broadband deployment reports to measure the percentage of Americans living on tribal lands with or without access to broadband, and to measure progress toward FCC's strategic goal of increasing all Americans' access to affordable broadband. By using broadband availability data to measure broadband access on tribal lands, FCC overstates broadband access on tribal lands. gao_GAO-19-8: Why GAO Did This Study In school year 2015-16, over 5 million students were enrolled in public high schools, according to Education data. Nearly 1.8 million (over 14 percent) attended schools where at least three-quarters of the students were experiencing poverty. GAO was asked to review the college preparation opportunities available to students in high-poverty schools. This report examines (1) the extent to which high schools of different poverty levels offer courses to prepare students academically for college and (2) describes challenges that students in high-poverty schools face in being prepared to attend college. GAO analyzed federal data on college preparatory course offerings by school poverty level quartiles; and within these quartiles, GAO analyzed student demographics and course offerings by school type, size, and locale. GAO also interviewed officials from state educational agencies, school districts, college advising organizations, and public 4-year colleges. GAO selected three states—California, Georgia, and Wisconsin—based on the percentage of students eligible for free or reduced-priced lunch and the number of courses offered by schools in each state. GAO also interviewed officials from state educational agencies, school districts, college advising organizations, and public 4-year colleges. What GAO Found High-poverty schools offer fewer of the courses that prepare students for public 4-year college at a glace: Students' access to more advanced high school courses decreased as the level of school poverty increased. High-poverty schools represented 17 percent of all high schools in 2015-16. College admissions officials from all four public, 4-year universities GAO interviewed reported that they look for students to take advanced courses in high school in order to be more competitive applicants. However, GAO's analysis of Education's school year 2015-16 data found that some high-poverty schools may not offer the math and science courses needed to meet basic admission expectations for public 4-year colleges. For example, an estimated 95 percent of colleges expected applicants to have completed three or four credits of math, but GAO found that the percentage of schools offering these recommended courses decreased as poverty level increased. gao_GAO-18-322: Why GAO Did This Study HHS-OIG has the authority to exclude providers and other entities that have committed certain acts from participation in federal health care programs. HHS-OIG has used this authority to negotiate agreements with entities that pose the highest risk of potential fraud. GAO was asked to review HHS-OIG's use of this authority. This report examines (1) the number and types of agreements HHS-OIG entered into from July 2005 through July 2017, and (2) the extent to which HHS-OIG uses its permissive exclusion authority to ensure compliance with agreements and to exclude entities for noncompliance. GAO analyzed HHS-OIG data from July 2005 through July 2017, reviewed HHS-OIG documents, and interviewed HHS-OIG officials. What GAO Found From July 2005 through July 2017, the Department of Health and Human Services' (HHS) Office of Inspector General (HHS-OIG) entered into 652 new agreements—an average of about 50 agreements per year—ranging from a high of 83 to a low of 37. The agreements were almost exclusively agreements with large corporations, and agreements with individual practitioners and entities such as small physician groups. HHS-OIG has used these agreements exclusively since 2010. From 2010 to July 2017, 74 percent of agreements have been agreements with larger corporations and 26 percent have been agreements with individual practitioners and entities such as small physician groups. HHS-OIG entered into agreements with a wide range of entities, but most were concentrated among a few types of entities. Specifically, HHS-OIG entered into agreements with 30 different types of entities, though slightly more than half of the agreements were with 3 types—individual/small group practices, hospitals, and skilled nursing facilities. Another quarter of the agreements were with medical group practices, pharmaceutical manufacturers, clinics, medical device manufacturers, and ambulance companies. HHS-OIG has criteria to determine whether to exercise its permissive exclusion authority, or take an alternate action, such as entering into an agreement with an entity. HHS-OIG has four broad categories of criteria that it applies in deciding where an entity falls on the risk continuum and which action to take. These four categories are (1) the nature and circumstances of the conduct; (2) conduct during the government's investigation; (3) whether the entity has made efforts to improve its conduct; and (4) the entity's history of compliance. gao_GAO-18-71: Why GAO Did This Study The United States is the world's largest consumer and commercial market for wireless devices. The demand for spectrum is expected to grow as companies bring new IoT technologies and services to market and government users. GAO was asked to examine the challenges facing federal spectrum managers and the steps they are taking to address those challenges. This report examines (1) the spectrum-related challenges stakeholders identified due to the anticipated growth of IoT, (2) steps FCC and NTIA are taking to plan for the anticipated growth in the demand for spectrum as a result of IoT, and (3) efforts that selected leading countries are undertaking to plan for IoT's spectrum needs and ways that these efforts compare with those of the United States. GAO reviewed relevant literature and interviewed officials from FCC and NTIA, and representatives from selected leading countries. GAO also surveyed trade journals, industry groups, and foreign governments' websites and publications. What GAO Found Stakeholders representing Internet-connected devices (IoT) network providers, device manufacturers, users, and federal regulators consistently identified two spectrum-related challenges to the continued growth and development of IoT: (1) ensuring the availability of sufficient spectrum and (2) managing the harmful interference from the increasing number of IoT devices. While not currently a crisis, the stakeholders GAO spoke to agreed that ensuring the availability of sufficient spectrum and the right kinds of spectrum is a key challenge for supporting the growth of IoT. Specifically, stakeholders cited three dimensions of the spectrum availability challenge: the amount, the balance between licensed and unlicensed, and the variety of spectrum bands available. According to some reports, incorrectly anticipating industry needs in any of these areas could weaken IoT growth and development in the United States. To plan for spectrum needs, the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) has repurposed spectrum by making additional spectrum available for commercial purposes and, according to FCC officials, the agency is continuing to look for additional opportunities to do so. This order follows a technology neutral approach to planning by allowing spectrum users to develop technologies for the spectrum and not have FCC dictate its specific use.
