gao_GAO-18-187T: Why GAO Did This Study The 2012 National Infrastructure Protection and Resiliency Act required the National Science Foundation (NIST) to establish a network to provide public safety information. The act also required that FirstNet develop a framework to meet the financial requirements established in the act. This testimony discusses (1) FirstNet's progress in establishing and financing the network and consulting stakeholders, and (2) FirstNet's network reliability, security, and interoperability challenges and efforts to address them. What GAO Found In its June 2017 report, GAO found that FirstNet has conducted key efforts to establish the network, namely releasing the request for proposal for the network in January 2016 and awarding the network contract to AT&T in March 2017. gao_GAO-18-39: Why GAO Did This Study The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) estimates that taxpayers should have paid an average of about $2.5 trillion dollars per year in federal taxes for tax years 2008 to 2010. IRS also estimates that taxpayers paid approximately $2.04 trillion voluntarily and on time for those years, on average, leaving $458 billion in unpaid taxes per year. However, IRS estimates that through late payments and enforcement actions it eventually will collect an additional $52 billion on average for those years, leaving the average net tax gap at $406 billion for 2008 to 2010. GAO was asked to review IRS's efforts to address the tax gap. This report (1) determines the main drivers of the tax gap; (2) IRS's confidence in the tax gap estimates; (3) IRS goals, if any, for reducing the tax gap; and (4) the extent to which IRS uses tax gap estimates and underlying data to develop strategies and actions to reduce the tax gap. GAO reviewed IRS's tax gap estimates and underlying data; reviewed IRS and Treasury documents; and interviewed IRS officials. IRS officials stated that the tax gap estimates are sufficiently reliable for the intended purpose of providing a snapshot of tax compliance as a whole. gao_GAO-18-164: Why GAO Did This Study The Departments of Labor (DOL), Justice (DOJ), and Health and Human Services (HHS) have a long history of requiring grantees to make hiring decisions based on religion. In 2007, the Office of Labor's (OLC) Office of Labor Policy (OLP) issued an opinion that questioned the extent to which DOJ, DOL, and HHS had a religious-based hiring policy. GAO was asked to review DOJ's religious-based hiring policy. This report examines (1) the extent to which DOJ, DOL, and HHS have statutory restrictions on religious-based hiring and (2) how DOJ, DOL, and HHS inform grantees of statutory restrictions on religious-based hiring and processes for obtaining an exemption from such restrictions. GAO reviewed relevant laws and regulations, and interviewed DOJ, DOL, and HHS officials. What GAO Found From 2007 to 2015, DOJ, DOL, and HHS awarded funding to at least 2,586 grantees through at least 53 grant programs that were subject to statutory restrictions on religious-based hiring. gao_GAO-18-184T: Why GAO Did This Study Radiation exposure can cause cancers, including leukemia and colon cancer. gao_GAO-19-47: Why GAO Did This Study The RFS is designed to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by replacing petroleum-based fuels with biofuels that have lower associated greenhouse gas emissions released throughout their lifecycle. The RFS requires blending ethanol with gasoline to demonstrate compliance with the program. GAO was asked to review the RFS. This report examines (1) what is known about the effect that the RFS has had on retail gasoline prices in the United States and (2) the effect that the RFS has had on greenhouse gas emissions. GAO analyzed RFS data, interviewed experts, and conducted semistructured interviews with 18 experts with expertise on these topics. What GAO Found Evidence from studies, interviews with experts, and GAO's analysis suggest that the Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS) was likely associated with modest price increases outside of the Midwest. The experts, stakeholders, and studies identified two main ways in which the RFS may have affected prices. Specifically, the RFS may have (1) increased transportation and storage costs in regions outside the Midwest, and (2) caused an initial increase in refining investment costs that over the long term reduced refining costs for gasoline. The RFS may have also affected retail gasoline prices by increasing transportation costs in certain regions. For example, the Midwest was already producing and blending ethanol, so it had lower transportation costs and had already built necessary storage infrastructure. Other regions began blending ethanol later as rising volumes of ethanol required under the RFS forced more ethanol into the system and as states began blending ethanol. These states incurred new transportation and storage infrastructure costs, which likely resulted in higher gasoline prices compared to those in the Midwest states or states that had not yet begun to blend ethanol. Overall, it is likely that as the expanded blending requirements of the RFS caused non-Midwestern states and localities to begin blending ethanol, these states and localities experienced increased gasoline prices of a few cents per gallon compared to what they otherwise would have been. Most of the experts GAO interviewed generally agreed that to date the RFS has likely had a limited effect, if any, on greenhouse gas emissions. However, the effect has been difficult to assess precisely and GAO found disagreement among some experts about whether the effect has been positive or negative. gao_GAO-18-135: Why GAO Did This Study The Coast Guard administers TAP, which provides training to servicemembers who are separating from the military. What GAO Found The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) does not have complete or reliable data on participation levels in the Transition Assistance Program (TAP), according to agency officials. According to agency officials, the most common factor affecting TAP participation, cited at 11 of the 12 Coast Guard installations GAO surveyed, pertained to servicemembers assigned to geographically remote locations. gao_GAO-18-257: Why GAO Did This Study Federal agencies collectively have billions of dollars' worth of personal property, ranging from office furniture to highly specialized equipment that, when in use, supports agency missions. GAO was asked to review federal agencies' management of personal property. gao_GAO-18-500: Why GAO Did This Study Many consumer products are differentiated to appeal specifically to men or women through differences in packaging, scent, or other product characteristics. These differences related to gender can affect manufacturing and marketing costs that may contribute to price differences in products targeted to different genders. GAO was asked to review issues related to gender-related price differences. This report examines (1) how prices compared for selected categories of consumer goods that are differentiated for men and women, and potential reasons for any significant price differences; (2) what is known about the extent to which men and women may pay different prices in, or experience different levels of access to, markets for credit and goods and services that are not differentiated based on gender; (3) the extent to which federal agencies have identified and taken steps to address any concerns about gender-related price differences; and (4) state and local government efforts to address concerns about gender-related price differences. GAO analyzed retail price data from Nielsen Company (Nielsen) for calendar year 2016 and reviewed academic literature on price differences. GAO also interviewed officials from the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection (BCFP), Federal Trade Commission (FTC), and Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD). GAO also reviewed a sample of consumer complaints from databases managed by BCFP, FTC, and HUD. What GAO Found In 5 out of 10 product categories GAO analyzed, personal care products targeted to women sold at higher average prices than those targeted to men after controlling for certain observable factors. For 2 of the 10 product categories, men's versions sold at higher average prices. While the factors GAO controlled for likely proxy for various costs and consumer preferences, GAO could not fully observe all underlying differences in costs and demand for products targeted to different genders. As a result, GAO could not determine the extent to which the gender-based price differences GAO observed may be attributed to gender bias as opposed to other factors. GAO reviewed studies that compared prices for men and women in four markets where the product or service is not differentiated by gender: mortgages, small business credit, auto purchases, and auto repairs. These studies found mixed evidence of differences in interest rates and access to credit. For example, one study found that women paid higher interest rates for certain subprime loans. However, the authors did not control for other factors that could affect borrowing costs, such as differences in education, shopping behaviors, and geographic location.

gao_GAO-18-8: Why GAO Did This Study USMS is responsible for ensuring that federal employees are selected based on merit. GAO was asked to review USMS's merit promotion process. This report examines (1) the extent to which USMS has aligned its merit promotion policy with federal guidelines and developed a consistent process, and (2) the extent to which USMS has taken steps to understand and address employee concerns about the merit promotion process. GAO reviewed relevant federal laws, regulations, and guidance; analyzed USMS data on employee views on the merit promotion process; and interviewed USMS officials. What GAO Found The U.S. Marshal Service (USMS) has aligned its merit promotion policy with federal guidelines and developed a consistent process. GAO determined that the USMS merit promotion policy aligns with relevant provisions of title 5 of the United States Code, and title 5 of the Code of Federal Regulations. Specifically, the most recent version of the USMS Merit Promotion Plan, which was revised in November 2016, outlines the mechanisms for affording merit staffing and promotional opportunities to competitive status candidates for GS-13, GS-14, and GS-15 1811 operational law enforcement positions. The plan states that it is the policy of the USMS to maintain a sound staffing program that will ensure that USMS fills positions from among the best qualified candidates and that the selection, assignment, and promotion of employees are on the basis of job-related criteria. USMS has developed a multi-step process based on its merit promotion plan to assess and select eligible candidates for promotion. gao_GAO-18-616T: Why GAO Did This Study The federal government has a long history of addressing management weaknesses that have contributed to mismanagement and a lack of accountability. However, Indian Affairs has not fully addressed 8 of the 23 outstanding education recommendations GAO identified in its September 2017 testimony, and GAO has closed them.

gao_GAO-18-141T: Why GAO Did This Study The Bureau is preparing for the 2020 Census, which is expected to cost about $12.5 billion (in 2020 dollars). gao_GAO-18-432T: Why GAO Did This Study SSA is the nation's largest disability program provider, providing benefits to about 62,000 federal employees and 15,000 state employees. SSA's disability programs are complex and costly to administer. GAO has reported on SSA's disability programs since 1990, and has identified a number of challenges that SSA faces in managing its programs and ensuring program integrity. This statement discusses (1) challenges SSA faces in managing its disability programs and ensuring program integrity, and (2) challenges SSA faces in modernizing its physical footprint and service delivery. This statement is based on GAO's body of work issued from January 2010 through February 2017, and selected updates conducted in February 2017 on SSA's progress in addressing GAO's prior recommendations. What GAO Found Complex eligibility rules and multiple handoffs and potential layers of review make SSA's disability programs complicated and costly to administer. Program complexity arguably has made it challenging for SSA to make significant advances in efficiently managing high disability workloads, ensuring timely and consistent disability decisions, preventing benefit overpayments, and mitigating fraud risks. GAO's recent work highlighted some of the challenges SSA faces in making disability decisions that are timely, consistent and based on current concepts of disability, while also preventing and deterring fraud and ensuring that only beneficiaries who are entitled to benefits receive them. These findings underscore the need for SSA leadership to approach these challenges strategically and follow through with rigorous plans in order to achieve significant improvements in its disability programs. GAO's recent work also highlighted some of the challenges SSA faces in making disability decisions that are timely, consistent and based on current concepts of disability, while also preventing and deterring fraud and ensuring that only beneficiaries who are entitled to benefits receive them. These findings underscore the need for SSA leadership to approach these challenges strategically and follow through with rigorous plans in order to achieve significant improvements in its disability programs.
gao_GAO-17-789: Why GAO Did This Study The Navy and Marine Corps have identified the need to rebuild the capability to conduct amphibious operations and to reinvigorate naval integration toward that end. GAO was asked to review the Navy's and Marine Corps' efforts to improve naval integration for amphibious operations. This report examines the extent to which (1) the Navy and Marine Corps have completed training for amphibious operations priorities and taken steps to mitigate any training shortfalls, (2) the Navy's and Marine Corps' efforts to improve naval integration for amphibious operations incorporate leading collaborative practices, and (3) the Marine Corps has integrated selected virtual training devices into its operational training. GAO reviewed Navy and Marine Corps documents and interviewed officials from the services' headquarters, components, and operating forces. What GAO Found The Navy and Marine Corps units that are deploying as part of an Amphibious Ready Group (ARG) completed their required training for amphibious operations, but several factors have limited the ability of Marine Corps units to conduct training for other amphibious operations-related priorities. For example, the Navy's fleet of amphibious ships has declined by half in the last 25 years, from 62 in 1990 to 31 today, with current shipbuilding plans calling for four additional amphibious ships to be added by fiscal year 2024, increasing the total number of amphibious ships to 35. The Navy and Marine Corps have taken steps to identify and address training shortfalls, but their efforts to mitigate these shortfalls have not prioritized available training resources, systematically evaluated among potential training resource alternatives to accomplish the services' amphibious operations training priorities, or monitored progress toward achieving them. Without such an approach, the services are not well positioned to mitigate existing amphibious operations training shortfalls and begin to rebuild their amphibious capability as the services await the arrival of additional amphibious ships into the fleet. The Navy and Marine Corps have taken some steps to improve coordination between the two services, but the services have not fully incorporated leading collaboration practices that would help drive efforts to improve naval integration for amphibious operations. GAO's prior work on interagency collaboration has found that certain practices can help enhance and sustain collaboration among federal agencies. For example, the Navy and Marine Corps have issued strategic documents that discuss the importance of improving naval integration, but the services have not fully established compatible policies and procedures, such as common training tasks and standards, to ensure their efforts

gao_GAO-18-240: Why GAO Did This Study GME training is a key component of health care workforce planning, and federal agencies fund GME training through five federal programs and 45 state Medicaid agencies. GAO was asked to review federal funding for GME training. This report examines (1) the amount of federal funding that federal agencies and state Medicaid agencies spent on GME training in 2015, and the extent to which these funds support GME training, and (2) the extent to which federal agencies collect information to manage their programs and ensure payments are accurate. GAO analyzed federal cost report data for 2015, reviewed literature, and interviewed federal and state officials and experts. What GAO Found Federal agencies and state Medicaid agencies spent over $16.3 billion on graduate medical education (GME) training in 2015, and the amount spent per full-time-equivalent (FTE) resident varied across programs, and the largest variation across payment recipients and regions was within Medicare due to variation in the values of factors used to calculate Medicare payment amounts. The amount spent per FTE resident varied across programs, and the largest variation across payment recipients and regions was within Medicare due to variation in the values of factors used to calculate Medicare payment amounts. Almost half of participants received payments from more than one program, and the designs of federal programs may reduce the potential for duplicate payments. GME training costs vary by program characteristics, such as size, type, training setting, and age, and some training costs are more prone to variation than others. Challenges exist in measuring and comparing GME training costs due to a lack of standard cost methodologies across teaching sites and some training costs being difficult to measure. Little is known about how GME training costs relate to federal GME funding. Agencies generally collect information to manage their respective programs, ensure the accuracy of payments, and reduce the potential for duplicative payments within or across federal programs that fund GME training. However, HHS does not have sufficient information available to comprehensively evaluate the federal programs that fund GME training, identify gaps between federal GME programs' results and physician workforce needs, and make or recommend to Congress changes in order to improve the efficient and effective use of federal funds. gao_GAO-18-291: Why GAO Did This Study Medicaid is the nation's largest health care program, with about $1.3 billion in outlays in fiscal year 2017. CMS estimates the national Medicaid improper payment rate at 0.3 percent, which is significantly lower than the 12.9 percent improper payment rate for Medicaid fee-for-service (FFS). GAO was asked to review CMS's oversight of Medicaid managed care. This report examines (1) the extent to which CMS's payment error rate measurement for managed care measures program integrity risks, and (2) the extent to which CMS and states ensure the identification and reporting of overpayments and unallowable costs. GAO reviewed relevant federal and state audits and investigations of Medicaid managed care programs, and interviewed CMS officials and state program integrity officials. What GAO Found The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services' (CMS) payment error rate measurement for Medicaid managed care measures the accuracy of the capitated payments state Medicaid agencies make to managed care organizations (MCO) on behalf of enrollees. However, the PERM does not account for other program integrity risks—such as overpayments to providers and unallowable MCO costs. For example, the PERM does not account for errors in capitated payments made to MCOs, which are payments made to MCOs for services that were not provided or medically necessary. In addition, CMS regulations state that overpayments in managed care include any payment made to an MCO or provider under contract to an MCO to which the MCO or provider is not entitled under Medicaid. As a result, the PERM improper payment estimate potentially understates the extent of program integrity risks in Medicaid managed care. Moreover, this potential understatement in the PERM's improper payment rate estimate may curtail investigations into the appropriateness of MCO spending. CMS has increased its focus on and worked with states to improve oversight of Medicaid managed care; however, these efforts and the oversight efforts of states do not ensure the identification and reporting of overpayments and unallowable costs. In recent years, CMS has sought to strengthen oversight of managed care programs through updated regulations; reviews of states' managed care programs (Focused Program Integrity Reviews); and state monitoring of overpayments. gao_GAO-18-539: Why GAO Did This Study The U.S. public transportation system is increasingly influenced by the "sharing economy," which is based on sharing, renting, and borrowing goods and services, rather than owning them. The Federal Transit Administration's (FTA) MOD program is a key effort to help local transit agencies explore emerging shared mobility technologies, in part by partnering with private mobility companies. GAO was asked to review partnerships. This report examines (1) the extent to which selected local transit agencies have partnered with private mobility companies to provide on-demand services, and (2) the potential impact of selected local transit agencies' partnerships on the future. GAO reviewed relevant federal laws, regulations, and FTA documents; analyzed FTA data on ridership and costs; and interviewed FTA officials and selected local transit agencies. What GAO Found Local transit agencies nationwide are pursuing partnerships to offer a variety of on-demand services that aim to make access to public transportation more efficient and convenient. The private mobility companies involved in selected partnerships include some well-known companies such as Uber and Lyft, and some lesser-known types of companies such as a bike-share company and technology companies focused on transportation. Selected local transit agencies most frequently partnered with ridesourcing companies (11 projects), while 8 partnership projects included more than one type of private partner. Five of the 22 partnership projects were in FTA's MOD Sandbox program. Most of the selected projects (14 of 22) involved on-demand first- and last-mile transportation connections, through which respective local transit agencies aim to increase ridership on their transit systems. Most of the selected projects (14 of 22) involved on-demand services targeted toward paratransit-eligible riders, either as the primary project goal or to ensure equivalent service for eligible customers. Most of the selected projects have not yet been evaluated to determine whether they achieved intended outcomes. However, a few transit officials told GAO that their agencies' costs had decreased since initiating the partnerships. For example, an official from one transit agency reported that the on-demand service provided through their partnership had helped them reduce costs for paratransit. Two of the completed partnerships generated insufficient ridership to succeed. The partnerships were widely covered by the press, which transit agency officials believe provides other transit agencies the opportunity to learn from them as well. gao_GAO-19-144: Why GAO Did This Study The federal government and private industry face a persistent shortage of cybersecurity and IT professionals to implement and oversee information security protections to combat cyber threats. The Federal Cybersecurity Workforce Assessment Act of 2015 required OPM, NIST, and other federal agencies to undertake a number of cybersecurity workforce-planning activities. The act also required OPM to provide agencies with timely guidance for identifying IT, cybersecurity, and cyber-related work roles of critical need. GAO was asked to review federal agencies' implementation of the act's selected activities. This report (1) determines the extent to which federal agencies have assigned work role codes to positions performing information technology (IT), cybersecurity, or cyber-related functions, and (2) describes the steps federal agencies took to identify work roles of critical need. GAO reviewed the act's provisions and OPM's guidance and interviewed agency officials. What GAO Found The 24 major departments and agencies covered by the Chief Financial Officers (CFO) Act of 1990 had generally assigned work role codes to their positions performing information technology (IT), cybersecurity, or cyber-related functions. However, several agencies had not completed assigning codes to their vacant positions. In addition, most agencies had likely miscategorized the work roles of many positions. For example, the 24 agencies routinely assigned work role codes to positions that were likely inconsistent with the positions' functions. For example, the 24 agencies assigned a code designated for positions that did not perform IT, cybersecurity, or cyber-related functions to positions that most likely performed these functions. The act required OPM to identify critical needs across federal agencies and submit a progress report to Congress on the identification of IT, cybersecurity, or cyber-related work roles of critical need by December 2017. OPM also required agencies to submit a preliminary report on work roles of critical need by August 31, 2018. The 24 agencies have begun to identify critical needs and submit preliminary reports to OPM. As of November 2018, OPM and the 24 agencies had taken steps to address the three selected activities required by the act. Specifically, OPM had reported on agencies' progress in identifying critical needs and had provided agencies with guidance for identifying IT, cybersecurity, and cyber-related work roles of critical need. In addition, the 24 agencies had submitted preliminary reports of their identified critical needs to OPM, but their efforts to identify critical needs were ongoing.
gao_GAO-18-417: Why GAO Did This Study The defense laboratories are responsible for a wide range of research, development, and engineering activities, including the development of nuclear weapons, nuclear materials, and other materials. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2017 included a provision for GAO to review the defense laboratories' hiring efforts. This report examines (1) the defense laboratories' use of existing hiring authorities and what officials view as the benefits of authorities and incentives and the challenges in hiring; (2) the extent to which the Department of Defense (DOD) evaluates the effectiveness of hiring, including hiring authorities, at the defense laboratories; and (3) the extent to which DOD has time frames for approving and implementing new hiring authorities. GAO analyzed DOD hiring data for fiscal years 2015 through 2017, and interviewed DOD, military service, and defense laboratory officials. What GAO Found The defense laboratories have used the defense laboratory-specific direct hire authorities more than any other category of agency-specific or government-wide hiring authority. For example, the direct hire authorities for candidates with advanced degrees were used for 55 percent of all direct hires, and the direct hire authorities for candidates with bachelor's degrees were used for approximately 36 percent of all direct hires. The defense laboratories' use of these hiring authorities increased each year from fiscal year 2015 through fiscal year 2017. For fiscal years 2015 through 2017, the defense laboratories used the defense laboratory-specific direct hire authorities more often than any other category of hiring authorities when hiring STEM personnel. Moreover, the defense laboratories' use of these hiring authorities increased each year from fiscal year 2015 through fiscal year 2017. For fiscal year 2017, the defense laboratories used the defense laboratory direct hire authorities for 54 percent of STEM hiring actions completed, representing an increase of approximately 16 percentage points relative to fiscal year 2015, when 38 percent were hired under defense lab direct hire authorities. However, even with access to the authorities, these defense laboratory officials identified challenges associated with the hiring process that affected their ability to hire highly qualified candidates. For example, the defense laboratories' flexibility in pay setting under their demonstration project authority was generally considered to be the most helpful incentive, with 13 of 16 survey respondents stating that this incentive had very much helped them to hire highly qualified candidates. However, even with access to the authorities, these defense laboratory officials identified challenges associated with the hiring process that affected their ability to hire highly qualified candidates. For example, the defense laboratories have lost quality candidates to the private sector, and the department-wide hiring freeze has delayed hiring
gao_GAO-19-84: Why GAO Did This Study NNSA is responsible for replacing the W78 nuclear warhead in U.S. nuclear weapons. The W78 is the only U.S. nuclear warhead that can be used in a nuclear explosive package. NNSA is responsible for developing and acquiring new nuclear components, such as lithium, for the W78. NNSA's W78 replacement program is intended to replace the W78 warhead in U.S. nuclear weapons. The program is currently suspended because of a lack of funding and other factors. GAO was asked to review the W78 replacement program. This report examines (1) steps NNSA has taken to prepare to restart a W78 replacement program and (2) the extent to which NNSA has identified the facilities and capabilities needed to provide the nuclear and nonnuclear components for a W78 replacement. GAO reviewed NNSA documents and interviewed NNSA officials. What GAO Found The National Nuclear Security Administration (NNSA) has taken steps to prepare to restart a program to replace the W78 nuclear warhead capability. NNSA has (1) taken initial steps to establish the program management functions needed to execute the program and assemble personnel for a program management team; (2) assessed technologies that have been under development while the program was suspended that could potentially be used to support a W78 replacement; and (3) initiated plans for the facilities and capabilities needed to provide the nuclear and nonnuclear components for the warhead. NNSA and the Department of Defense (DOD) officials stated that, in response to the 2018 Nuclear Posture Review, they planned to restart a program that would focus on replacing the capabilities of the W78 for the Air Force; however, the extent to which the program would focus on providing a nuclear explosive package for the Navy was uncertain. DOD officials said that the Navy plans to complete a study examining the feasibility of using the nuclear explosive package developed for the W78 replacement warhead in its SLBM system by the end of fiscal year 2019. According to DOD officials, the Nuclear Weapons Council will make a decision about developing an interoperable warhead for the Air Force and the Navy based on the results of the study but, as of August 2018, had not established time frames for making that decision. According to Air Force and NNSA officials, if the Nuclear Weapons Council decided that the Navy should participate in the program, then NNSA would not need to redo the work
gao_GAO-18-290: Why GAO Did This Study The federal government invests billions of dollars annually in STEM education programs to enhance the nation's economic and educational competitiveness. The National Science and Technology Council's Committee on STEM Education and the Office of Science and Technology Policy have responsibilities for coordinating federal STEM education efforts. GAO was asked to review the extent to which federal STEM education programs have been funded in fiscal year 2016. This report examines (1) the extent to which federal STEM education programs have been funded in fiscal year 2016, and (2) the extent to which the Committee has assessed the effectiveness of the portfolio of STEM education programs. GAO analyzed agency data on the number of STEM education programs and spending in fiscal year 2016, and interviewed agency officials. What GAO Found Program officials from the 13 federal agencies that administer STEM education programs reported a total of 163 STEM education programs in fiscal year 2016, compared to 209 programs in fiscal year 2010. Three agencies—the Department of Energy, the Department of Health and Human Services, and the National Science Foundation—administered more than half of all STEM education programs in fiscal years 2010 and 2016. Despite collectively reporting fewer STEM education programs, program officials responding to GAO's questionnaire reported spending about the same amount in fiscal year 2016 as they did in fiscal year 2010. In fiscal year 2016, program officials reported spending about $2.9 billion on the 163 programs. The National Science Foundation and the Department of Health and Human Services programs account for about 60 percent of this spending. Many of the 163 STEM education programs in fiscal year 2016 overlapped with at least one other STEM education program, in that they offered similar services to similar groups in similar STEM fields to achieve similar objectives. Similarities occurred among programs funded in fiscal year 2010. Many of the 163 programs had similar objectives, such as providing training opportunities for undergraduate or graduate students in STEM fields. However, some programs served distinct populations within those broader groups, such as minority, disadvantaged, or underrepresented groups. The Committee on STEM Education and the Office of Science and Technology Policy have not fully met their responsibilities to assess the STEM education portfolio. Specifically, the Committee has not reviewed performance assessments of STEM education programs to ensure effectiveness—a primary function of its authorizing charter. The Committee has not documented the outcomes of programs' performance assessments in its federal STEM education inventory. By periodically documenting in its federal STEM education inventory whether programs have been assessed for effectiveness, the Committee could enhance communication of performance information among agency officials and stakeholders.
gao_GAO-19-57: Why GAO Did This Study Federal agencies hold billions of dollars in real property assets, including roads, bridges, and buildings. GAO was asked to review federal agencies' efforts to manage their real property assets. This report examines (1) key characteristics of an effective asset management framework, and how selected federal agencies' frameworks reflect these characteristics; (2) views of selected asset management experts and practitioners on challenges and benefits to implementing an asset management framework; and (3) whether government-wide asset management guidance and information reflect standards and key characteristics of an effective asset management framework. GAO reviewed relevant literature, analyzed fiscal year 2017 Federal Real Property Profile data, and interviewed officials from six federal agencies selected based on their size, mission, and experience in managing their assets. GAO also interviewed representatives from private industry, federal agencies, and local municipalities in Canada, which have developed and implemented asset management practices. What GAO Found Based on GAO's review of asset management literature, asset management literature, and interviews with experts, GAO identified six key characteristics of an effective asset management framework: (1) establishing formal policies and plans, (2) maximizing an asset portfolio's value, (3) maintaining leadership support, (4) using quality data, (5) promoting a collaborative organizational culture, and (6) evaluating and improving asset management practices. Each of the six agencies GAO reviewed had a real property asset management framework that included some of these key characteristics. However, agencies varied in how they performed activities in these areas. For example, while some agencies' asset management policies applied to large portions of their portfolios, other agencies' policies applied to only certain portions of their portfolios. In addition, two agencies—the Corps and Coast Guard—told GAO they were using the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) 55000 standards. For example, according to Corps officials, the Corps is in the process of incorporating elements of the ISO 55000 standards into its frameworks. Coast Guard officials told GAO they were using the ISO 55000 standards as a benchmark to compare against their existing framework. According to GAO's review of asset management literature, establishing formal policies and plans can help agencies take a more strategic approach in their asset management decision making and identify key roles and responsibilities, resources required to implement their plans, potential implementation obstacles and strategies for overcoming these obstacles. In addition, each of the six agencies GAO reviewed had developed a formal asset management plan in response to Executive Order 133
gao_GAO-18-606: Why GAO Did This Study Substance use is a leading cause of death in the United States, and the federal government provides grants to help address this problem. GAO was asked to review federal grant programs that address substance use prevention, treatment, and recovery services among adolescents and young adults. gao_GAO-18-348: Why GAO Did This Study DOD established the Exceptional Family Member Programs (EFMP) in 2010 to help military families with special needs identify and gain access to programs and services at their current, as well as proposed, locations. The NDAA for Fiscal Year 2017 included a provision for GAO to assess the effectiveness of the EFMP. This report examines (1) the extent to which each Service has provided family support as required by DOD, and (2) the extent to which the Services monitor and DOD evaluates assignment coordination and family support. GAO reviewed relevant federal laws, regulations, and DOD guidance and documentation; analyzed fiscal year 2016 EFMP data; and interviewed DOD, Service, and nonfederal officials. What GAO Found Key aspects of support for families with special needs vary widely across the Department of Defense's (DOD) four Services, leading to potential gaps in assistance for families with special needs. DOD officials said each Service provides family support services in accordance with DOD guidance as well as Service-specific guidance. However, GAO found wide variation in each Service's requirements for family support personnel as well as the practices and expectations of EFMP staff. As a result the type, amount, and frequency of assistance enrolled families receive varies from Service to Service and when a servicemember from one Service is assigned to a joint base led by another Service. For example, in terms of a minimum level of contact for families with special needs enrolled in the EFMP, the Services vary in the frequency with which they require family support providers to contact families with special needs. The Services also vary as to whether they offer legal assistance to families with special needs. DOD has specifically required each Service to develop and maintain a services plan (SP) for each family with special needs, and DOD has specifically required these plans as part of the provision of family support services. However, DOD has not developed a standard for determining the sufficiency of funding and resources each Service allocates for family support. Without fully identifying and addressing potential gaps in family support across these programs, some families with special needs may not get the assistance they require, particularly when they relocate. Each Service has mechanisms to monitor assignment coordination and family support activities, but DOD lacks common performance measures and a process to fully evaluate these activities. DOD requires each Service to monitor implementation of their EFMP, including procedures for assignment
gao_GAO-18-449: Why GAO Did This Study DOD has used the Global Train and Equip program to provide training, equipment, and small-scale military construction activities intended to build partner nations' military forces to conduct counterterrorism operations. The fiscal year 2017 National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) included a provision for GAO to conduct biennial audits of such programs. This report examines (1) the status of funding that DOD allocated for Global Train and Equip projects in 2009 through 2017, (2) the extent to which DOD addressed security assistance planning elements in project proposals in 2016 and 2017, and (3) DOD's reporting on the achievement of Global Train and Equip project objectives and any factors affecting its ability to achieve those objectives. GAO analyzed DOD funding data, program guidelines, project proposal documents, and congressional notifications; reviewed DOD's assessment reports and supporting documents; and interviewed DOD officials. What GAO Found Of the $4.1 billion allocated for Global Train and Equip projects in 2009 through 2017, the Department of Defense (DOD) has obligated approximately $3.7 billion and disbursed $2.5 billion. DOD allocated the funds for Global Train and Equip projects in 2009 through 2017, according to the fiscal year in which DOD allocated the funds. DOD allocated the funds for Global Train and Equip projects in Jordan and Lebanon, which received a combined total of $856 million, or 47 percent of total allocations during that period. DOD's 2016 and 2017 proposals for Global Train and Equip projects consistently addressed only one of the four planning elements called for by DOD guidance, but agency officials reported implementing an informal process to improve coverage of these planning elements in 2018 proposals. DOD's 2016 and 2017 guidance called for proposal packages to address (1) project objectives, (2) partner nation absorptive capacity, (3) baseline assessments of partner nation capabilities, and (4) project sustainment needs. All 72 proposal packages GAO reviewed for 2016 and 2017 included project objectives. Slightly more than 30 percent of proposal packages in 2016 and over 80 percent in 2017 included information about partner nations' absorptive capacity, compared with 19 percent in 2015. However, less than three-quarters of proposal packages in 2016 and 2017 included complete sustainment plans, with the percentage that did so declining from 73 percent in 2016 to 68 percent in 2017. DOD's 2016 and 2017 guidance called for proposals to address sustainment planning, but it did not provide instructions for doing so
gao_GAO-19-44: Why GAO Did This Study The U.S. Department of the Treasury (Treasury) provides the Judgment Fund, a permanent, indefinite appropriation, to pay many types of eligible monetary claims that may be judicially or administratively ordered against the U.S. government. The Judgment Fund is also available to pay interest and costs on claims in certain circumstances. In connection with its oversight efforts, the House Committee on the Judiciary (Committee) requested certain information from Treasury about Judgment Fund balances, activities, and other information. GAO was asked to (1) evaluate the extent to which the information Treasury provided to the Committee responds to the Committee's May 2017 request for information about Judgment Fund balances and activities and reconciles to financial information included in annual, audited financial reports and other selected reports and (2) describe the Bureau of the Fiscal Service's documented procedures and related control activities for processing agency requests for payments from the Judgment Fund, including how Fiscal Service ensures that appropriate agency official approve claims and what reviews are required, if any, to ensure receipt of required documentation. gao_GAO-19-103: Why GAO Did This Study FMD is a highly contagious viral disease that causes fever and painful lesions on cloven-hoofed animals' hooves, mouths, and udders. gao_GAO-18-158: Why GAO Did This Study The Navy plans to spend over $267 billion to design, build, and procure the Columbia class submarine. The Navy expects to spend about $8.7 billion over the next several decades to build the lead submarine. The Navy has requested $8.7 billion for lead ship construction. Congress included a provision in statute for GAO to review the Columbia class program. This report examines (1) the status of key Columbia class technologies and congressional reporting requirements on this status, (2) risks, if any, with the Navy's planned approach for design and construction, and (3) whether expected funding levels for the Columbia class will be adequate moving forward. GAO reviewed program documentation and interviewed relevant officials from the Navy, the Navy's Columbia class program office, and the prime contractor shipyard General Dynamics Electric Boat. What GAO Found The Navy has made progress in reducing technical risks in many areas, such as starting construction of the first Columbia class nuclear reactor, but several key technologies remain immature as the Columbia class program moves into its design phase. These include the integrated power system, nuclear reactor, and propulsor/coordinated stern. While the Navy made progress in some areas—such as prototyping efforts for the missile compartment and nuclear reactor—all of these systems continue to require development and testing to mature them to the point at which GAO's technology readiness guide considers a technology mature. Any challenges in development could put the program at risk of costing more, taking longer to develop, or jeopardizing the program's ability to meet its expected performance requirements. However, the Navy identified only two of the submarine's technologies as “critical” in the program's 2015 technology readiness assessment (TRA), thereby underrepresenting the technology risk in the program. Underreporting technical risks can hinder Congress' and other decision makers' full understanding of the program's progress. gao_GAO-18-315: Why GAO Did This Study Recovery housing—a term that includes a range of services and resident requirements—is an important step in the continuum of care for individuals recovering from substance abuse (SUD). This report examines (1) the prevalence of recovery housing in the United States, (2) actions taken by selected states to investigate and oversee recovery housing, and (3) the extent to which SAMHSA and state funding can be used for recovery housing. Reclamation awards grants to project sponsors under the Title XVI program to help them plan, design, or construct infrastructure for the treatment and distribution of reused water. The Water Infrastructure Improvements for the Nation Act (WIIN Act) authorized an additional $50 million to be appropriated for water reuse projects. GAO was asked to review the Title XVI program. This report examines (1) the amount of funding Reclamation awarded under the Title XVI program from fiscal years 1992 through 2017, (2) the types of projects and studies that have been funded under the Title XVI program, and (3) the extent to which Reclamation's project selection process is consistent with relevant federal grant regulations. GAO reviewed agency documents and interviewed agency officials and project sponsors. GAO also reviewed federal grant regulations and interviewed project sponsors. What GAO Found The Bureau of Reclamation (Reclamation) awarded about $715 million for 46 construction projects and 71 studies under the Title XVI Water Reclamation and Reuse Program (Title XVI) from fiscal years 1992 through 2017, according to agency documents. Most of this funding—about $703 million—went toward construction projects, while the remaining awards were for feasibility and research studies. Some construction projects remain eligible for Title XVI grants. Specifically, about $464 million in grant funding not yet awarded up to the federal ceiling remains for individually congressionally authorized Title XVI construction projects, and about $513 million remains in total estimated projects eligible for Title XVI grants under the WIIN Act, as of August 2018. Title XVI projects and studies for fiscal years 1992 through 2017 cover various uses for reused water and include both urban and rural areas throughout the West, based on GAO's review of agency documents and interviews with project sponsors. For example, Title XVI projects produce both nonpotable and potable reused water for a variety of purposes, such as landscape irrigation, agricultural irrigation, commercial and industrial use, and habitat restoration. gao_GAO-18-611T: Why GAO Did This Study In fiscal year 2016, FNS served 149 million meals to children through its SFSP program. FNS is responsible for administering the program and overseeing the program's operations. This testimony discusses (1) the number of SFSP meals served nationwide during the summer, (2) the extent to which other federal and nonfederal programs helped feed low-income children in the summer, and (3) challenges states and SFSP providers reported in implementing the program. This statement is based on GAO's May 2018 report, Food for Low-Income Children: Federal and Nonfederal Programs Helped Feed Low-Income Children in the Summer (GAO-2018-08-28). GAO reviewed FNS data on SFSP meals served nationwide from 2007 through 2016, and interviewed FNS officials and national organizations. What GAO Found The total number of Supplemental Food for School Program (SFSP) meals served nationwide during the summer—one indicator of program participation—increased from 113 million meals in fiscal year 2007 to 149 million meals in fiscal year 2016, or by 32 percent. Although almost half of the total increase in meals served in the summer months was due to increases in lunches, when comparing across each of the meal types, supper and breakfast had the largest percentage increases over the 10-year period, 50 and 48 percent, respectively. The increase in SFSP meals over this time period was generally consistent with increases in the number of meals served in the National School Lunch Program (NSLP), the largest child nutrition assistance program, during this period. Although FNS clarified its instructions in May 2017 to help improve the consistency of states' statewide estimates of children's participation in SFSP, ADA, even if consistently calculated, remained an unreliable estimate of children's daily participation in SFSP for at least two reasons. First, ADA did not account for existing variation in the number of days that each site serves meals to children. Second, ADA did not account for state variation in the month with the greatest number of SFSP meals served. According to FNS officials, the agency instructed states to calculate ADA for July because officials identified this as the month with the largest number of meals served nationwide. However, according to GAO's analysis of nationwide FNS data, in summer 2016, 26 states served more SFSP meals in June or August than in July
gao_GAO-18-114: Why GAO Did This Study The growth of e-commerce has greatly increased the likelihood of businesses selling to out-of-state customers. In 1992, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled in Quill Corp. v. North Dakota that a state can only require a business to collect and remit sales tax if the business has substantial presence, referred to as nexus, in that state. However, the decision stated that Congress could pass legislation to overrule the Quill decision. GAO was asked to review the potential revenue gains states could gain by collecting taxes on sales made by all remote sellers. This report examines (1) the extent to which state and local governments can require remote sellers to collect taxes on all sales, (2) the costs associated with collecting taxes on all remote sales, and (3) strategies that could mitigate these concerns. GAO analyzed state and local sales tax data, reviewed relevant literature, and interviewed state and local officials. What GAO Found GAO estimates that state and local governments can, under current law, require remote sellers to collect about 75 to 80 percent of the taxes that would be owed if all remote sellers were required to collect tax on all remote sales at current rates. GAO estimates that about 80 percent of the potential revenue from requiring all Internet retailers to collect is already collectible. For business-to-consumer (B2C) remote sales, GAO estimates that the percentage of taxes already being collected by sellers was generally higher for Internet retailers than for other types of remote sellers like catalog retailers or e-marketplaces. GAO estimates that about half of potential revenue gains to state and local governments would result from collecting sales taxes on all e-marketplace sales. To date, e-marketplaces have not been obligated to collect state sales taxes on behalf of sellers. Instead, like with all remote sellers, individual sellers who have title to the goods being sold through an e-marketplace are required to collect tax on sales to states in which they have nexus. However, GAO identified two states that have recently taken action to attribute a collection obligation to the e-marketplace. gao_GAO-18-102: Why GAO Did This Study Water utilities provide drinking water and wastewater services, including drinking water treatment and distribution and wastewater collection, treatment, and discharge. Water utilities employ a broad range of workers, including water operators; engineers; customer service representatives; accountants; legal support; and skilled technical occupations, such as electricians, machinists, and instrument technicians. GAO was asked to review workforce challenges at water utilities. This report examines (1) what is known about workforce needs at water utilities compared with workforce needs nationwide and any effects of potential unmet workforce needs on the utilities' abilities to comply with the Safe Drinking Water Act and the Clean Water Act; (2) what approaches selected water utilities have used to manage their workforce needs and challenges they have faced in managing those needs; and (3) how key federal programs can assist water utilities with their workforce needs. GAO reviewed relevant federal laws and regulations, analyzed EPA compliance data, and interviewed officials from five federal agencies that conduct activities or provide funding related to the water utility workforce. What GAO Found Data available from the Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) suggest that the workforce replacement needs for water operators are similar to workforce replacement needs nationwide across all occupations. However, little information is available about the current and future effects of any unmet workforce needs on utilities' abilities to comply with the Safe Drinking Water Act and the Clean Water Act. BLS projects that there will be 9,200 job openings for water operators between 2016 and 2026. However, little information is available about the current and future effects of any unmet workforce needs on utilities' abilities to comply with the Safe Drinking Water Act and the Clean Water Act. The most recent BLS projections indicate that the replacement needs for water operators—resulting from retirement or other separations—are relatively similar to the projected national average of replacement needs across all occupations (8.2 percent versus 10.9 percent, respectively). However, little information is available about the current and future effects of any unmet workforce needs on utilities' abilities to comply with the Safe Drinking Water Act and the Clean Water Act. At a national level, neither the water utilities' industry associations nor EPA has analyzed whether there is a relationship between unmet workforce needs and compliance problems. gao_GAO-18-592: Why GAO Did This Study DOD provides human resources services to other defense agencies and organizations, such as the Defense Logistics Agency (DLA), the Defense Finance and Accounting Service (DFAS), and the Washington Headquarters Service (WHS), among others. gao_GAO-18-585T: Why GAO Did This Study In 2013, CMS reported that about 61 percent of beneficiaries in the Medicare Part D program were at risk of opioid use disorder, overdoses, or abuse. CMS has a goal of reducing the risk of opioid use disorder, overdoses, and abuse. GAO was asked to review CMS's oversight of opioid prescribing. This statement discusses (1) CMS's oversight of beneficiaries who receive opioids, and (2) CMS's oversight of providers who prescribe opioids to Medicare Part D beneficiaries. This statement is based on GAO's October 2017 report, Medicare Part D: Overutilization Monitoring System (GAO-17-92). GAO reviewed CMS guidance and data on beneficiaries who received opioids, and interviewed CMS officials. What GAO Found The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) delegated monitoring of beneficiaries who receive opioids to plan sponsors, but did not have sufficient information on those most at risk for harm. CMS created the Overutilization Monitoring System (OMS) in 2013 to identify beneficiaries with high-risk use of opioids, and to oversee sponsors' compliance with CMS's opioid overutilization policy. CMS also reported a 61 percent decrease from calendar years 2011 through 2016 in the number of beneficiaries meeting the OMS criteria of high risk—from 29,404 to 11,594 beneficiaries—which agency officials considered an indication of success toward its goal of decreasing opioid use disorder. However, CMS did not have comparable information on most beneficiaries who receive high doses of opioids—regardless of the number of providers and pharmacies used—and who therefore may be at risk for harm, according to CDC's 2016 guidelines. These guidelines noted that long-term use of high doses of opioids—those above a MED of 90 mg per day—are associated with significant risk of harm and should be avoided if possible. CMS has revised its current OMS criteria to include more at-risk beneficiaries beginning in 2018. However, CMS did not keep track of the total number of these beneficiaries, and did not have plans to do so as part of OMS. GAO also found that CMS oversees providers who prescribe opioids to Medicare Part D beneficiaries through its contractor and plan sponsors. CMS required the contractor to identify providers who prescribe high amounts of opioids, which include but are not limited to opioids. CMS's guidance focused broadly on prescription drugs, and did not specifically address opioids
gao_GAO-18-660T: Why GAO Did This Study Fraud is a significant risk to Medicare and Medicaid programs, and is estimated to cost the Medicare program at $1.5 trillion in 2028. What GAO Found The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services' (CMS) antifraud efforts partially aligned with the Fraud Risk Framework. Consistent with the framework, CMS has demonstrated commitment to combating fraud by creating a dedicated entity to lead antifraud efforts. CMS has also taken steps to establish a culture conducive to fraud risk management, although it could expand its antifraud training to include all employees. Without a fraud risk assessment, CMS cannot be certain that it is aware of the most-significant fraud risks facing this program and what risks it is willing to tolerate based on the program's size and complexity. gao_GAO-18-310: Why GAO Did This Study Rail transit is an important component of the nation's transportation network, providing over 4.4 billion passenger trips in 2016. FTA oversees safety of railroads and rail transit systems, which are a network of standard gage track over which goods may be transported and passengers may travel. The 112th Congress included a provision in the Federal Surface Transportation Reform Act of 2012 that, among other things, provided FTA with authority to issue safety regulations and to establish a state safety oversight program. The act also required GAO to review FTA's oversight of rail transit. This report examines (1) FRA's and FTA's approaches to rail transit safety oversight, and (2) FTA's and FTA's efforts to implement its new authorities. GAO reviewed FRA and FTA documents, interviewed FTA and rail stakeholders, and analyzed FTA and rail safety studies. What GAO Found The Federal Railroad Administration (FRA) and the Federal Transit Administration (FTA) have a more centralized safety oversight program for railroads, while FTA is implementing changes to the rail transit oversight program, established in federal statute, which relies on states to monitor and enforce safety. FRA's safety regulations include minimum safety requirements, though railroads can apply for waivers. FRA's inspections are guided by a risk-based model, which focuses its inspections on locations that, according to FRA's data-driven model, are likely to have safety problems. FRA has hired additional inspectors, going from 347 inspectors in fiscal year 2013 to over 360 currently, out of the nearly 930 full-time equivalent staff agency-wide. FRA and FTA's approaches to their rail safety oversight missions each have strengths and limitations, including how the agencies develop safety regulations, conduct inspections, and carry out enforcement. Compared to FRA's long-standing role in providing safety oversight over railroads, FTA is in the process of implementing significant changes to its program for rail transit safety oversight after being granted new authorities in the Moving Ahead for Progress in the 21st Century Act (MAP-21) and the Federal Surface Transportation Reform Act of 2012. FRA's extensive and well-established safety regulations are a strength of FRA's safety oversight program. FTA has sought to address previously identified deficiencies in state safety oversight by recommending that state safety agencies develop risk-based inspection
gao_GAO-18-443: Why GAO Did This Study The 2013 amendments to the S.Republic Act of 2013 (SRIA) allow tribes to make a direct request to the President for federal disaster assistance. The act also allows tribes to make a sub-recipient request under certain circumstances. GAO was asked to review tribes' experiences requesting and managing disaster declarations. This report examines (1) the factors that influence selected tribes' decisions about how to seek federal assistance through a major disaster declaration and (2) the actions FEMA is taking to assist tribal efforts to request and manage disaster declarations. GAO surveyed 36 tribes that requested or joined a state's request for major disaster declarations from 2013 through 2016 and interviewed officials from FEMA and two national tribal organizations. GAO also visited 7 tribes selected from among the 23 tribes that responded to a survey. What GAO Found According to the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) data, between 2013 and 2016, 36 tribes made requests for disaster assistance as a direct recipient or by joining a state's request. Of those 36 tribes, 17 tribes made a total of 17 direct requests to the President through FEMA for major disaster declarations. Eight of these requests were approved across 7 tribes. Twenty-nine tribes were sub-recipients under 36 state major disaster declaration requests. Eight tribes made a direct request and also joined at least one state request for a major disaster declaration. Tribal officials reported that there are several factors they considered when deciding whether to make a direct request or to join a state's request for a disaster declaration, during the 2013 to 2016 period. Specifically, nine of 10 tribes responding to GAO's survey that made a direct request reported that tribal sovereignty was a major factor they considered when making a direct request. In addition, nine of 10 tribes responding to GAO's survey that made a direct request reported that the clarity of FEMA's policies and guidance was a factor in their decision making. Conversely, eight of the 13 tribes that only joined a state request reported that their concerns about FEMA's policies and guidance were a factor in their decisions. Tribal officials' confidence in the tribe's emergency management capacity was a key factor in determining whether or not to seek a request directly or to join a state's request.
gao_GAO-18-96: Why GAO Did This Study The U.S. commercial space launch industry has achieved several milestones since 1984. In fiscal year 2017, the Office of Commercial Space Transportation had 104 full-time equivalent positions and an operations budget of $19.8 million. In 1995, the Department of Transportation (DOT) transferred the office's responsibilities from DOT to FAA. In 2014, Congress moved the Office of the Secretary of Transportation to FAA. GAO was asked to review the potential benefits and disadvantages of moving the office. This report examines (1) stakeholders' perspectives on moving the office and (2) steps that can be taken to move the office. GAO reviewed relevant laws, regulations, and other documents and interviewed officials from FAA, DOT, and the Office of the Secretary of Transportation. What GAO Found Representatives from the commercial space launch companies and spaceports GAO spoke to described both potential advantages and disadvantages of moving the office, but most of them favored moving the office. FDA has a variety of incentives for orphan drugs, including a tax credit that allows drug manufacturers to charge higher prices for orphan drugs. GAO was asked to review FDA's orphan drug program. This report examines (1) steps FDA has taken to address the demand for orphan designations, and (2) the extent to which FDA's orphan drug marketing approvals are consistent with its criteria. GAO reviewed FDA data on orphan designation applications received from 2008 to 2017, reviewed 148 OOPD review templates, and interviewed FDA officials and stakeholders. What GAO Found The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has implemented a number of steps under its Orphan Drug Modernization Plan to address the demand for orphan designations, and has recently met its timeliness goals. In June 2017, FDA issued its Orphan Drug Modernization Plan and has implemented a number of steps under the plan to address the demand for orphan designations. According to OOPD data, the number of new designation applications received grew from 185 in 2008 to 527 in 2017 (an increase of 185 percent), while the number of designations granted also grew during the same period. To accomplish its first goal, the modernization plan outlined seven actions FDA planned to take to temporarily increase OOPD resources for reviewing designation applications. For example, the agency established an experienced team of senior OOPD reviewers to focus solely on the backlog of designation applications. In addition, OOPD initially enlisted temporary assistance from the Center for Biologics Evaluation and Research (CBER) and the Center for Drug Evaluation and Research (CDER) reviewers who expressed interest in helping clear the backlog. As a result of these efforts, FDA cleared the application backlog by August 28, 2017, nearly a month ahead of its goal. FDA generally applies consistent criteria in reviewing applications for orphan designation, but did not ensure that all required information was consistently recorded in its review templates and evaluated when making designation decisions. For example, 102 of 148 review templates were missing one or more elements of the regulatory history of a drug, and 19 of 148 review templates did not capture all prior orphan designations for the drug and disease. gao_GAO-18-397T: Why GAO Did This Study The U.S. Border Patrol is responsible for securing the southwest border, which includes the San Diego and Rio Grande Valley sectors. The Border Patrol has invested over $2.4 billion in tactical infrastructure, such as fencing, and has also faced challenges in maintaining this infrastructure. In January 2017, the Border Patrol issued an executive order that called for the hiring of 5,000 additional Border Patrol agents, subject to available appropriations. This statement discusses (1) the status of CBP's efforts to deploy surveillance technology along the southwest border and assess the contributions of surveillance technologies to border security operations, and (2) the extent to which CBP has assessed the impact of existing fencing on border security operations. This statement is based on GAO products issued from February 2011 through November 2017, selected updates conducted in March 2018, and ongoing work. GAO reviewed relevant documents and interviewed officials from DHS, the Border Patrol, and other organizations. What GAO Found The Department of Homeland Security's (DHS) Customs and Border Protection (CBP) has made progress deploying surveillance technology along the southwest border, but has not fully assessed its effectiveness. In November 2017, GAO reported on the progress the Border Patrol had made deploying technology along the southwest border in accordance with its 2011 Arizona Technology Plan and 2014 Southwest Border Technology Plan. For example, according to officials, the Border Patrol had completed deployments of all planned Remote Video Surveillance Systems (RVSS), Mobile Surveillance Capability systems, and Unattended Ground Sensors, as well as 15 of 53 Integrated Fixed Tower systems to Arizona. In addition, the Border Patrol had efforts underway to deploy other technology programs, but at the time of GAO's report, some of those programs had not yet begun deployment or were not yet under contract. For example, in November 2011, GAO reported that CBP did not have the information needed to fully support and implement the Arizona Technology Plan and recommended that CBP (1) determine the mission benefits to be derived from implementation of the Arizona Technology Plan and (2) develop and apply key attributes for metrics to assess program implementation. CBP concurred with GAO's recommendations and has implemented one of them. Specifically, in March 2014, GAO reported that CBP had identified mission benefits of its surveillance technologies to be deployed along the southwest border, such as improved situational awareness and agent safety. However, the agency had not developed key attributes for performance metrics for all surveillance technologies to be deployed.

gao_GAO-19-167: Why GAO Did This Study SNAP is intended to help low-income households obtain a more nutritious diet by providing them with benefits to purchase food from authorized retailers nationwide. gao_GAO-18-605: Why GAO Did This Study The Air Force has a fleet of HH-60Gs, which are used to support the active and reserve components of the Air Force. gao_GAO-18-607: Why GAO Did This Study In fiscal year 2016, Medicaid covered an estimated 72.2 million low-income and medically needy individuals in the United States. gao_GAO-18-60: Why GAO Did This Study Seismic surveys are used to collect data on the presence of oil and gas in the Outer Continental Shelf (OCS), which includes the Atlantic, Gulf of Mexico, and Pacific. BOEM, NMFS, and FWS review applications for seismic surveys in each of these OCS regions. This report examines (1) BOEM's process for reviewing seismic survey permit applications in each OCS region, the number of applications reviewed from 2011 through 2016, and BOEM's review time frames; (2) NMFS's and FWS's processes for reviewing incidental-take authorization applications related to seismic surveys in each OCS region, the number of such applications reviewed by the agencies from 2011 through 2016, and their review time frames; and (3) the status of pending seismic survey permit applications and related incidental take authorizations in the Atlantic OCS region. GAO reviewed relevant laws and regulations, analyzed agency data, and interviewed agency officials and industry stakeholders. What GAO Found The Bureau of Ocean Energy Management (BOEM) has a documented process for reviewing seismic survey applications in each of the three selected OCS regions that differs at the final step. For the Gulf of Mexico region, BOEM generally issues permits without requiring incidental take authorizations to be in place. Stakeholders from industry groups and BOEM officials GAO interviewed stated that differences in the review process were the natural result of the process adapting to the three selected OCS regions and their history of oil and gas exploration. For example, in the Atlantic region, there was a large vocal public opposition to the seismic surveys proposed. By contrast, according to industry stakeholders, the Gulf of Mexico region has a long history of offshore energy development and seismic survey activity. gao_GAO-18-635: Why GAO Did This Study The Bureau estimates the cost of the 2020 Census to be $12.3 billion, an increase of 27 percent over its 2015 estimate. What GAO Found The U.S. Census Bureau (Bureau) has made progress in developing its life-cycle cost estimate for the 2020 Census, but it has not taken all the steps needed to ensure the reliability of the estimate. gao_GAO-18-262: Why GAO Did This Study Whistleblowers at NASA are a key component of the agency's mission. GAO also reviewed a generalizable sample of contracts awarded in fiscal year 2016 to determine the extent to which NASA communicated whistleblower protections to its contractors and their employees. What GAO Found From 2008 to June 2017, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's (NASA) Office of Inspector General (OIG) investigated whistleblower reprisal complaints within required time frames. gao_GAO-18-40: Why GAO Did This Study Drug companies are involved in the research, development, distribution, and payment for chemically synthesized and biologic drugs. The federal government supports R&D for new drugs through grants and tax incentives administered by the Internal Revenue Service. In addition, mergers and acquisitions affecting the drug industry are subject to review by the federal government to ensure compliance with applicable antitrust laws. GAO was asked to review drug industry consolidation. This report examines (1) how the financial performance and structure of the drug industry have changed over time; and (2) how reported research and development spending and new drug approvals have changed. GAO analyzed data from the Bloomberg Terminal, a publicly available source of information on drug companies, from 2006 through 2015, and reviewed relevant literature. GAO also interviewed officials from the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), the Internal Revenue Service (IRS), and the National Institutes of Health (NIH), which fund research and development (R&D), and other federal agencies. What GAO Found Among the worldwide drug companies included in the data GAO reviewed, reported pharmaceutical and biotechnology sales revenue and profit margins for most companies grew from 2006 through 2015. The number of mergers and acquisitions among companies in the industry generally held steady from 2006 through 2015, but merger and acquisition deal values increased. Market concentration varied by the specific market level considered. Industry experts GAO interviewed noted that market pressures have driven structural changes in the drug industry, such as in the types of acquisitions and increased specialization in therapeutic areas. Pharmaceutical company-reported R&D spending grew slightly from 2008 through 2014, while federally funded spending decreased slightly over the period. Industry spending focused on drug development rather than earlier-stage research, whereas direct federal spending, such as through NIH grants, funded a greater amount of basic research. Claims for the orphan drug credit, one of several federal tax incentives encouraging drug development, increased sharply from 2005 through 2014. Biologics and orphan drugs accounted for an increasing share of new drug approvals from 2005 through 2016. Studies GAO reviewed and experts GAO interviewed suggested that potential revenues, costs, and policy incentives influenced brand-name drug company R&D investment decisions.
gao_GAO-18-220: Why GAO Did This Study Medicaid is the nation's largest health care program, with about $1.3 trillion in outlays in fiscal year 2015. gao_GAO-18-361: Why GAO Did This Study TRICARE, a federal health plan, provides health care coverage to about 2.2 million beneficiaries, including those who are not eligible for TRICARE. GAO analyzed DOD's 2012-2015 nonenrolled beneficiary and civilian provider surveys, interviewed DOD officials, and analyzed 190 geographic locations. What GAO Found Nationwide, a lower percentage of nonenrolled beneficiaries reported that they experienced problems finding any type of provider in the 2012-2015 survey (29 percent) compared to the prior 2008-2011 survey (31 percent). However, there was no significant statistical difference over time in the percentage of beneficiaries who reported experiencing problems finding a specialty care or mental health care provider. Nonenrolled beneficiaries' positive ratings of TRICARE have generally increased since the previous survey, and nonenrolled beneficiaries' positive ratings of their mental health care providers have generally decreased. Civilian providers' awareness of TRICARE has generally increased over time, while mental health providers' acceptance of new TRICARE patients has decreased. Nationwide, a higher percentage of civilian providers reported that they were aware of TRICARE in the 2012-2015 civilian provider survey (84 percent) than those from the 2008-2011 civilian provider survey (82 percent). However, awareness increased for specialty care providers (92 to 94 percent) and mental health care providers (68 to 74 percent). In addition, when GAO analyzed these results by provider type and location type, GAO found that civilian providers in both PSAs and non-PSAs reported higher awareness of TRICARE than nonnetwork providers, regardless of provider type.
