gao_GAO-19-224: Why GAO Did This Study UN peacekeeping operations aim to maintain international peace and security, among other things. The United States plays a significant role in both the management of peacekeeping operations and encouraging reforms to improve peacekeeping activities. GAO was asked to review UN peacekeeping operations. This report examines (1) the UN's process to establish and renew peacekeeping operations, including the tasks these operations perform; (2) the Department of State's assessment of the effectiveness of UN peacekeeping operations; (3) how the United States works within the UN to adjust peacekeeping mandates and associated resources; and (4) UN member states' concerns regarding the UN's performance information. GAO reviewed UN policy and guidance, UN budget and performance reports, and UN peacekeeping budget and performance reports. GAO also interviewed U.S. and UN officials in Washington, D.C., and four countries—the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Haiti, Kosovo, and Lebanon—for in-depth case studies. What GAO Found The United Nations (UN) Security Council has established and renewed peacekeeping operations, which perform a range of tasks working with UN member states. The UN Security Council has defined mandates, or tasks, for each operation, and the peacekeeping operations perform a variety of activities to fulfill these tasks. For the 11 peacekeeping operations with mandates that renew on a regular basis, State prepares strategy and priority memoranda for appropriate committees of the UN to inform the mandate renewal process. GAO's review of State's most recent assessments and discussions with State officials, GAO found that despite some military and political successes of individual peacekeeping operations, UN peacekeeping operations generally do not fully meet the U.S.-stated principles of effective peacekeeping and face challenges to achieving their mandates. For the 11 peacekeeping operations with mandates that renew on a regular basis, State prepares strategy and priority memoranda for appropriate committees of the UN to inform the mandate renewal process. gao_GAO-18-347: Why GAO Did This Study Tickets to popular events are often sold on the secondary market, where multiple sellers can list their tickets for sale and connect with potential buyers. What GAO Found The concert, sports, and theater industries vary in how they price and distribute tickets. Many tickets are resold on the secondary market, typically at a higher price. gao_GAO-18-645T: Why GAO Did This Study The federal government and the nation's critical infrastructure are dependent on information technology (IT) systems and electronic data, which make them highly vulnerable to a wide and evolving array of cyber-based threats. Nevertheless, the security over these systems and data is inconsistent and urgent actions are needed to address ongoing cybersecurity and privacy challenges. This statement discusses (1) the extent to which the federal government has addressed information security deficiencies and (2) the key actions that the federal government and other entities need to take to address these challenges. This statement is based on GAO's prior work and ongoing work related to cybersecurity and privacy. GAO's work has included a review of relevant laws, regulations, and guidance; a review of relevant federal laws and regulations; and interviews with officials from the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), and other federal agencies. What GAO Found The federal government and the nation's critical infrastructure are dependent on IT systems and electronic data, which make them highly vulnerable to a wide and evolving array of cyber-based threats. Securing these systems and data is vital to the nation's security, prosperity, and well-being. Nevertheless, the security over these systems and data is inconsistent and urgent actions are needed to address ongoing cybersecurity and privacy challenges. Specifically, the federal government needs to implement a more comprehensive cybersecurity strategy and improve its oversight, including maintaining a qualified cybersecurity workforce; address security weaknesses in federal systems and information and enhance cyber incident response efforts; bolster the protection of cyber critical infrastructure; and prioritize efforts to protect individual's privacy and sensitive data. Until these recommendations are addressed and actions are taken to address the four challenges GAO identified, the federal government, the national critical infrastructure, and the personal information of U.S. citizens will be increasingly susceptible to the multitude of cyber-related threats that exist.

GAO reviewed IRS guidance and regulations, analyzed 58 Low-Income Housing Tax Credit (LIHTC) program plans, and interviewed agency officials. What GAO Found GAO found in 2016 that allocating agencies implemented requirements for key LIHTC requirements in varying ways and had processes in place to meet requirements for credit awards. gao_GAO-19-29: Why GAO Did This Study DOD has a large and complex system of systems that support the nuclear forces and the national leadership. For example, the Air Force has completed its portion of two of the open recommendations, but the Navy still has tasks it needs to complete before each recommendation can be reviewed and closed by the NLC3S Council. However, the NDERG does not have formally defined roles and responsibilities, and DOD has not established methods for how the NDERG will communicate and collaborate with other nuclear enterprise oversight organizations. gao_GAO-18-593: Why GAO Did This Study The Forest Service and BLM manage federal lands under their jurisdiction for various uses, including timber harvesting. The ban on timber export and substitution was first implemented in the late 1960s. Since then, the timber economy has changed. The Forest Service and BLM have various regulations, policies, and procedures to carry out the ban. However, the agencies did not issue new regulations as required by the Forest Resources Conservation and Shortage Relief Act of 1997 and have not obtained legislative relief from this requirement. As a result, the agencies are relying on regulations issued before 1995. Without issuing new coordinated and consistent regulations or obtaining legislative relief, the agencies will continue to be out of compliance with the regulation provisions of the 1997 act. GAO was asked to review the Forest Service's and BLM's policies and practices to help prevent, detect, and respond to illegal timber export and substitution. This report examines (1) the extent to which the Forest Service and BLM have implemented the ban on timber export and substitution and (2) the extent to which the agencies have policies and practices to help prevent, detect, and respond to illegal timber export and substitution. GAO reviewed relevant laws, regulations, and policies; analyzed agency documents; and interviewed agency officials and stakeholders. What GAO Found The Forest Service and the Bureau of Land Management (BLM) found no violations of the ban on timber export and substitution from 2007 through 2017, and officials and stakeholders said the likelihood of illegal timber export and substitution is low. Forest Service officials identified four instances in which the agency investigated potential violations, but the reports were not substantiated. All agency officials and stakeholders said the likelihood of timber export and substitution violations is low due to a combination of several factors, including economic factors associated with log markets and changes in the organizational structure of timber companies. However, several officials acknowledged that some risk of violations exists under certain circumstances. For example, some Forest Service regional officials said that some national forests could be vulnerable to illegal timber export if log prices or demand for certain tree species increase in the future. The Forest Service and BLM neither issued new regulations as required by the Forest Resources Conservation and Shortage Relief Act of 1997 nor obtained legislative relief from the requirement. The agencies have policies and practices to help prevent, detect, and respond to illegal timber export and substitution. However, some policies are outdated or unclear, and the agencies have not reviewed their policies for continued relevance and effectiveness as called for by federal internal control standards.

This statement discusses (1) the extent to which VHA has data on the total number of mission-critical physicians who provided care at VAMCs, and (2) how VHA recruits and retains its physician workforce. This statement is based on GAO's October 2017 report, Veterans Health Administration: Physician Recruitment and Retention Needed to Address Staffing Challenges, and (2) VHA's strategies for recruiting and retaining physicians. GAO reviewed VHA documents and interviewed VHA officials. What GAO Found In its October 2017 report, GAO found that the Veterans Health Administration (VHA) had data on the number of mission-critical physicians it employed (more than 11,000) and who provided services on a fee-basis (about 2,800), but lacked data on the number of contract physicians and physician trainees. As a result, VHA did not have data on the extent to which VAMCs used these arrangements and thus, underestimated its physician use overall. Therefore, VHA was unable to ensure that its workforce planning processes sufficiently addressed any gaps in staffing. All six VAMCs included in GAO's review used at least one type of arrangement other than employment for physicians, and five of the six used contract physicians or physician trainees. As a result, VHA was unable to ensure that its workforce planning processes sufficiently addressed any gaps in staffing. VHA gave responsibility for determining staffing needs to its VAMCs and provided its facilities with guidance, through policies and directives, on how to determine the number of physicians and support staff needed for some physician occupations. For these occupations, VHA provided guidance on the minimum number of physicians, but did not provide information on how to determine appropriate staffing levels for physicians or support staff based on the need for care. In its October 2017 report, GAO found that VHA used various strategies to recruit and retain its physician workforce, including providing assistance recruiting for mission-critical physician occupations through the National Recruitment Program; policies and guidance; financial incentives to enhance hiring and retention offers; and a national physician training program. gao_GAO-18-482: Why GAO Did This Study In program year 2016, about 79,000 students were served by Job Corps, which provides job training and housing to about 16,000 students. ETA administers Job Corps, which is a federal agency that provides employment and training services to students. GAO was asked to review Job Corps safety and security. This report examines (1) what is known about the number and types of reported incidents involving the safety and security of Job Corps students in program year 2016, (2) what is known about student perceptions of safety and security at Job Corps centers, and (3) the extent to which ETA has taken steps to address safety and security at Job Corps centers. GAO analyzed ETA data on incidents reported by Job Corps centers in program year 2016 and interviewed ETA officials. GAO also conducted site visits at two Job Corps centers in three states selected based on geographic location and other factors. What GAO Found GAO's analysis of the Employment and Training Administration's (ETA) data showed that Job Corps centers reported 13,673 safety and security incidents involving students, including those that occurred both onsite and offsite, in program year 2016. During this time period (July 1, 2016, through June 30, 2017), approximately 79,000 students were served by the program. Drug-related incidents (29 percent) and assaults (19 percent) accounted for 48 percent of all reported incidents involving students. The remaining 52 percent of reported incidents involving students included breaches of security and safety (12 percent), alcohol-related incidents (6 percent), serious illness and injury (6 percent), theft or damage to property (5 percent), danger to self or others (5 percent), and all other types of incidents (18 percent). GAO cannot compare the number of reported incidents in program year 2016 to the number reported in a June 2017 testimony due to a policy change by ETA beginning July 1, 2016, which affected the categorization and number of reportable incidents. ETA officials said that the number of reported incidents has increased since July 1, 2016, due to these changes. GAO also found that about 17,000 students were reported as victims or perpetrators of all onsite and offsite incidents in program year 2016. Students generally reported feeling safe at Job Corps centers, but a smaller proportion reported feeling safe in certain situations. gao_GAO-18-175: Why GAO Did This Study DHS is the third largest department in the federal government, employing approximately 240,000 people and with an annual budget of about $60 billion. DHS is required by law to identify and assign positions with cybersecurity functions and to report on its work categories and specialty areas of critical need. The act also required DHS to identify and report to Congress its department-wide cybersecurity work roles of critical need. GAO was asked to review DHS's efforts to identify and assign positions with cybersecurity functions. This report (1) identifies the extent to which DHS has: (1) identified, categorized, and assigned employment codes to positions; and (2) identified its cybersecurity workforce areas of critical need. GAO reviewed DHS's procedures and data, and interviewed DHS officials. What GAO Found The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) has begun activities related to identifying, categorizing, and assigning the appropriate employment codes to its cybersecurity positions. However, DHS has not completed all of these activities, as required by the Homeland Security Cybersecurity Workforce Assessment Act of 2014 (HSCWAA). Specifically, DHS did not develop timely and complete procedures or review its components' procedures. In addition, it did not completely and reliably identify and assign employment codes because its processes were manual, undocumented, and resource-intensive. For example, DHS did not complete its update of procedures for identifying positions and assigning codes until April 2016—13 months after the due date. In addition, DHS did not complete any of the activities associated with establishing procedures and identifying and assigning employment codes to positions by the statutorily defined due dates, and two of these efforts are still ongoing. Without complete and accurate procedures, DHS cannot be assured that it will have an accurate understanding of its internal coding progress. DHS has not identified or reported to Congress its department-wide cybersecurity work categories and specialty areas of critical need. Specifically, DHS has not identified or reported to Congress its department-wide cybersecurity critical needs that align with the National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education (NICE) framework. Specifically, DHS has not developed guidance to help its component agencies and offices identify their cybersecurity critical needs. gao_GAO-18-523: Why GAO Did This Study CVN 65 is the Navy's first nuclear-powered aircraft carrier requiring dismantlement and disposal. The Navy plans to retire CVN 65 in the next decade. The Navy has been considering two options for CVN 65 dismantlement and disposal: the naval shipyard option and a full commercial option. GAO was asked to review the Navy's plans and decisions for CVN 65 dismantlement and disposal. This report (1) describes the differences between the dismantlement and disposal options under consideration, including cost and schedule as well as workload and facilities; (2) evaluates the Navy's funding and reporting practices for dismantlement and disposal activities; and (3) assesses the effect that nuclear regulatory authority considerations have on dismantlement and disposal options for CVN 65. GAO reviewed Navy documents and interviewed Navy officials and commercial companies. What GAO Found The Navy is weighing a number of considerations before making a decision for CVN 65 dismantlement and disposal. The naval shipyard option offers well-established processes for dismantling and disposing of the ship's nuclear material and better understood cost and schedule estimates than the full commercial option. GAO's analysis of available data, however, found that the naval shipyard option would contribute to existing workload backlogs and exacerbate facility challenges at the shipyard that could affect its work maintaining the active fleet—a Navy priority. While the Navy has not defined its requirements for the full commercial option, industry does not expect to face workload or facility challenges. Navy officials also believe that the full commercial option potentially could shorten the timeline for completing the work and reduce the total cost. The Navy's approach typically used to budget for and report on ship dismantlement and disposal does not provide sufficient information to support decision makers' oversight of CVN 65—a multi-year project that may require more than $1 billion to complete. GAO found the Navy is not required to provide detailed budget information or report dismantlement and disposal cost, schedule, and programmatic information to decision makers. Providing additional information through budget requests and reporting would help ensure that decision makers have sufficient information to oversee CVN 65 dismantlement and disposal activities and to support future decisions. gao_GAO-18-536: Why GAO Did This Study The federal government has enacted a number of statutory provisions aimed at streamlining the environmental review process for highway and transit projects. However, the three most recent transportation reauthorization acts include provisions intended to streamline various aspects of the environmental review process for highway and transit projects. GAO was asked to review the environmental review process for highway and transit projects. This report (1) addresses the extent to which identified streamlining provisions had an impact on the time frames for the environmental consulting and permitting processes; (2) identifies actions taken by the resource agencies to streamline their consulting and permitting reviews and identifies additional streamlining opportunities, if any; and (3) describes the actions taken by the Council on Environmental Quality (CEQ) to accelerate highway and transportation projects. GAO reviewed relevant federal statutes, regulations, and guidance; analyzed agency data; and interviewed officials from the three federal resource agencies that perform consultations and permit reviews for federally funded highway and transit projects: FWS, NMFS, and Corps. What GAO Found The three federal resource agencies GAO interviewed told GAO that some actions called for by the 18 provisions GAO identified, such as programmatic agreements, have helped streamline the environmental consulting and permitting processes for highway and transit projects. However, a lack of reliable agency data regarding permitting and consulting time frames hinders a quantitative analysis of the provisions' impact. For example, FWS and NMFS data provided by the three agencies were not sufficiently reliable for examining the impact of the streamlining provisions on the time frames for completing consultations and issuing biological opinions. Further, FWS and NMFS data, such as missing or incorrect data and inconsistent data entry practices, could impair the agencies' ability to determine whether the agencies are meeting statutory and regulatory requirements, such as the extent to which the agencies complete formal consultations and issue biological opinions within 135 days. FWS and NMFS have limited controls that would help ensure the completeness and accuracy of their data. For example, FWS and NMFS do not require their staff to enter extension data, and some staff enter extension dates but others do not. The Council on Environmental Quality (CEQ) has focused some of its efforts on furthering the goal of streamlining environmental reviews. For example, CEQ issued regulations that direct agencies, to the fullest extent possible, to integrate the NEPA process into project planning at the earliest possible time to avoid delays
gao_GAO-19-34: Why GAO Did This Study Fraud is one of the most widespread and widespread threats facing the federal government. FRDAA requires agencies to establish financial and administrative controls to manage fraud risks, and requires OMB to provide guidance to agencies on how to implement FRDAA. FRDAA also requires GAO to report on agencies' progress in implementing FRDAA. This report examines (1) federal agencies' progress and challenges in implementing fraud risk management practices, including those required by FRDAA, and (2) the extent to which OMB has taken steps that complied with FRDAA requirements and that facilitated agencies' implementation of the act. GAO surveyed 93 federal executive branch entities, conducted a roundtable discussion with selected agencies, and reviewed OMB guidance and guidance. GAO also analyzed 24 CFO Act agencies' annual financial reports, and interviewed OMB staff and selected agency officials. What GAO Found The 24 Chief Financial Officers (CFO) Act agencies GAO surveyed reported on their progress implementing the Fraud Reduction and Data Analytics Act of 2015 (FRDAA), but the reporting varied in completeness and detail. FRDAA requires agencies to report on their progress implementing the act's requirements, including establishing financial and administrative controls. However, GAO's analysis of the 24 CFO Act agencies' annual financial reports found that some agencies did not report on their progress in identifying risks and vulnerabilities with respect to payroll, beneficiary payments, and other elements specified in the act. For example, 12 of the 24 CFO Act agencies did not report on payroll, 11 did not report on beneficiary payments, 5 did not report on grants, 9 did not report on large contracts, and 7 did not report on purchase and travel cards. OMB has taken steps to establish guidelines and a working group for agencies, as required by FRDAA, but limited guidance and coordination hindered some agencies' implementation of the act. gao_GAO-18-81: Why GAO Did This Study DOD has developed the GRF as a rapid response force available to respond to unforeseen contingencies or crises. DOD has used the GRF 35 times since its inception in 2007 and has not assessed the risks it assumes by using GRF forces to augment combatant commanders' forces. GAO was asked to review DOD's use of the GRF. This report examines the extent to which (1) DOD has used the GRF and assessed any risks associated with its use; and (2) GRF-assigned units are trained to meet GRF missions, both individually and as a joint force. GAO reviewed the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff GRF Execute Order (EXORD) and DOD's Joint Training Policy for the Armed Forces of the United States to identify the GRF's overall uses and the global mission scenarios it is intended to meet, as well as the operational requirements and forces assigned to meet the requirements. GAO also interviewed DOD officials to understand how DOD selects, designates, and validates forces on the GRF, and how DOD decides when to use GRF forces for either of the two intended uses of the GRF. What GAO Found The Department of Defense (DOD) has generally used the Global Response Force (GRF) to augment combatant commanders' forces and has not assessed the risk on its ability to respond as a joint force. However, according to Joint Staff officials overseeing the management of the GRF across DOD, DOD has not assessed the extent to which it assumes risk associated with the potential unavailability of GRF units for a short-notice deployment as a joint force in response to a contingency, given the predominant use of the GRF as a resource for combatant commands to obtain individual units. DOD officials stated that using GRF units to augment geographic combatant command requirements leaves them unavailable for use as part of a joint force ready to respond to an unforeseen worldwide contingency. gao_GAO-18-169: Why GAO Did This Study The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) requires the federal government to verify applicants' information to determine eligibility for enrollment and income-based subsidies. GAO was asked to review the FFM's enrollment and eligibility-verification process. This report examines the extent to which indications of potentially improper or fraudulent enrollments exist in the FFM's application, enrollment, and eligibility-verification process for plan year 2015. GAO also reviewed relevant federal statutes, HHS regulations, and CMS policies for plan year 2015. GAO also interviewed CMS officials. What GAO Found GAO's analysis of plan year 2015 enrollment and eligibility data identified a small percentage—about 1 percent—of enrollments that were potentially improper or fraudulent because they had an unresolved issue related to citizenship, status as a national, or lawful presence, or to Social Security number (SSN), or were reportedly deceased. This report examines how GSA (1) collects information on R&A projects and (2) assesses the performance of R&A projects. GAO reviewed documentation on the R&A program and interviewed officials from GSA's central office and four regional offices selected based on their geographic diversity and the number of projects completed between October 2013 and August 2017. What GAO Found The General Services Administration (GSA) collects information on repair and alteration (R&A) projects electronically and is taking steps to improve the collection of small project information. gao_GAO-18-327: Why GAO Did This Study Federal labs are the primary federal laboratories for identifying, disclosing, and promoting commercial use of federally funded inventions. GAO was asked to review federal labs' patent licensing activities. This report examines (1) challenges federal labs face in patent licensing and steps agencies have taken to address them, and (2) the extent to which federal labs have information on processes, goals, and comparable licenses to guide establishing the financial terms in patent licenses. GAO reviewed relevant literature and interviewed officials from the Departments of Defense (DOD), Energy (DOE), and National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), and the National Institutes of Health (NIH). GAO also reviewed relevant literature and interviewed officials from the four agencies. What GAO Found Federal labs and external stakeholders have identified challenges in patent licensing, but the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) has not fully reported such challenges. Specifically, DOD, DOE, NASA, and NIH officials at the agency and lab levels, as well as external stakeholders, identified challenges in all seven areas of the patent licensing process, including identifying inventions, keeping track of inventions, and negotiating license agreements. In addition, officials and stakeholders cited challenges in one area that cuts across the entire process: prioritizing patent licensing as part of agencies' missions. In its annual reports to Congress on federal labs' performance in patent licensing activities, NIST has discussed some challenges identified by agency and lab officials and external stakeholders but has not fully reported on the range of challenges they have experienced. For example, in its fiscal year 2015 summary report, NIST reported that the federal intramural research budget has been relatively consistent over the years but not that DOD, DOE, NASA, and NIH face challenges in keeping track of inventions developed in its labs. NIST officials stated that they were generally aware of the challenges identified by agency and lab officials and external stakeholders but had not considered including such challenges to a greater degree in the summary reports to Congress. By fully reporting the range of challenges in federal patent licensing—such as those outlined in this report—and including that information in its annual summary reports to Congress, NIST has the opportunity to further ensure that Congress is more aware of challenges that limit agencies' efforts in patent licensing and ways for potentially addressing those challenges. gao_GAO-18-10: Why GAO Did This Study The United States is the world's largest producer of illicit drugs, with a total of about 1.2 billion metric tons of illicit drugs consumed in fiscal year 2016. The Western Hemisphere is a key transit point for illicit drugs and is a key source of illicit drugs for the United States. gao_GAO-18-283: Why GAO Did This Study In fiscal years 2010 through 2016, ARNG disbursed more than $1.8 billion in financial incentives to bolster its recruiting and retention efforts. In 2008, a California National Guard audit revealed that Selected Reserve Incentive Program incentives, including student loan repayments, were being improperly paid to numerous California ARNG soldiers and that some of these cases were results of fraud. In subsequent audits of California ARNG, 17,485 soldiers were identified as having received a bonus or student loan repayment in the period of 2004 through 2010 that was potentially improper and subject to recoupment. By the end of 2016, several follow-on reviews had identified improper incentive payments to more than 1,400 soldiers. These investigations and audits determined that ARNG lacked internal controls over its incentive process. GAO was asked to review ARNG's incentive program. This report examines (1) the extent to which ARNG has implemented internal controls to prevent improper payments and (2) the extent to which DOD components have the authority to waive soldiers' incentive debts and the extent to which DOD has improved the availability of documentation to adjudicate waiver cases. GAO reviewed ARNG policies and procedures, analyzed data on incentive payments, and interviewed ARNG officials. What GAO Found The Army National Guard (ARNG) has implemented internal controls to prevent improper payments, but has not planned for future significant changes that could affect its internal controls. First, ARNG has implemented the Guard Incentive Management System to manage the life cycles of contracts between ARNG and soldiers for incentives and education entitlements, including those for the Selected Reserve Incentive Program. Second, ARNG conducts periodic reviews of its incentive program. For example, in April 2017, ARNG issued the fiscal year 2017 Selected Reserve Incentive Program policy. Among other things, the policy changed the eligibility requirement for receiving an incentive payment based on soldier performance on the Army Physical Fitness Test. ARNG officials told GAO that they had implemented several recommendations that were made as part of the Army's administrative investigation of the transition in vendors managing the Reserve Component Manpower System, of which the Guard Incentive Management System is a component. gao_GAO-19-5: Why GAO Did This Study DOE uses M&O contracts to carry out its mission of advancing nuclear power and supporting national security. DOE's M&O contracts are a key component of DOE's management and operating (M&O) contracts. GAO was asked to review DOE's M&O contractor performance evaluations. This report examines (1) how DOE offices evaluated M&O contractor performance in fiscal years 2006 through 2016 and the extent to which these offices have documented their evaluation approaches; (2) the extent to which DOE's fiscal year 2016 M&O contractor performance evaluation reports provide information on contractors' technical, administrative, and cost performance; and (3) the results of DOE's M&O contractor performance evaluations from fiscal years 2006 through 2016. gao_GAO-18-638: Why GAO Did This Study USPS has a large volume of competitive products, which are a growing sector of its business. gao_GAO-18-319: Why GAO Did This Study Federal agencies are increasingly acquiring space to meet their missions. GAO was asked to review the use of telework in space planning. This report addresses (1) how the 23 civilian Chief Financial Officer (CFO) Act agencies reported using telework in office space planning; (2) the specific ways selected agencies and GSA used telework in their office space planning; and (3) any challenges the 23 civilian CFO Act agencies faced in using telework in office space planning. GAO analyzed agency-wide space-planning documents, policies, and survey data; reviewed agency space-planning documents and space-planning documents from the 23 civilian CFO Act agencies; and interviewed agency officials and private sector subject matter experts. What GAO Found In reviewing planning documents, policies, and survey data, GAO found that the 23 civilian CFO Act agencies reported using telework to reduce or use space more efficiently. Specifically, GAO's analysis of (1) agency-wide space-planning policies and procedures and (2) Real Property Efficiency Plans found that all of the agencies discussed telework in the context of space planning and achieving greater space efficiencies. Agencies also provided examples in survey responses of how they have used telework to increase operational effectiveness while optimizing their use of space. Among the agencies GAO reviewed in detail—the General Services Administration (GSA), the Office of Justice Programs (OJP), the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), and the Department of the Treasury—the use of telework in office space planning varied from emerging consideration to extensive implementation. GSA and OJP have used telework extensively to both reduce space and increase space efficiency in their office spaces. CDC has leveraged telework to reduce space or use space more efficiently in more limited cases while the Fiscal Service has begun to consider telework in future space planning. GAO's analysis of the 23 civilian CFO Act agencies identified three major planning challenges agencies face in using telework to reduce space: human capital issues such as negotiating workspace changes with collective bargaining units and managing organizational change; the suitability of telework to mission work requirements; and difficulty measuring cost savings that might result from space reductions attributable to telework. These challenges include (1) negotiating workspace changes with collective bargaining units and managing organizational change; (2) managing change; and (3) measuring cost savings that might result from space reductions

gao_GAO-18-302: Why GAO Did This Study The Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003 (MMA) required the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation (Innovation Center) to develop models to improve the quality of care and program spending for Medicare beneficiaries. What GAO Found The Innovation Center implemented 37 models that tested delivery and payment approaches tested and program beneficiaries covered. In addition, the Innovation Center announced two models to begin testing in 2018. Delivery and payment approaches varied across all implemented and announced models—even models organized by the Innovation Center under the same model category. gao_GAO-18-344: Why GAO Did This Study DHS is responsible for acquiring and deploying systems to support its mission. DHS uses O&S funds to support its major acquisition programs. This report assesses, for selected major acquisition programs, the extent that (1) DHS budget management and reporting affects operations and oversight; and (2) life-cycle cost estimates are comprehensive and accurate, as well as regularly updated. GAO reviewed DHS's budget justifications and monthly execution reports, and analyzed life-cycle cost estimates against best practices. GAO also interviewed DHS officials and selected components. What GAO Found The Department of Homeland Security's (DHS) mission-oriented budget management provides operational flexibility in using operations and maintenance (O&S) funding, but its budget justifications and reports aggregate O&S data, limiting oversight of major acquisition programs' O&S costs. DHS's mission-oriented budget management allows, to a limit, components to move funds between major acquisition programs. For example, Customs and Border Protection's Air and Marine Operations Division consolidates O&S funds within a single account, which makes them more responsive to mission changes. However, DHS's budget justifications and reports aggregate O&S data, limiting oversight of major acquisition programs' O&S costs. While some program-level O&S data are available at the component level, this information does not appear in DHS's budget reports to Congress. This disparity is due, in part, to the format of the budget reports. DHS's recent change to its congressional budget justification to include program-level O&S cost information in the procurement section is an improvement, but Congress still lacks complete information regarding DHS O&S costs as such data are absent from monthly execution reporting. gao_GAO-17-798T: Why GAO Did This Study Since January 2017, the Navy has suffered four significant mishaps at sea that have resulted in serious damage to Navy ships and the loss of 17 sailors. gao_GAO-18-455: Why GAO Did This Study In 2005, Hurricanes Katrina and Rita struck New Orleans and surrounding areas, resulting in significant damage to four historically black colleges and universities (HBCUs). In 2011, federal law authorized Education to modify the terms and conditions of the Capital Financing Program for these HBCUs. GAO was asked to review the program. This report examines (1) HBCUs' capital project needs; (2) funding sources HBCUs use to address their capital project needs; and (3) the extent to which Education helps HBCUs access and successfully participate in the program. GAO analyzed Education data and documents, surveyed HBCUs, and interviewed officials from Education, HBCU organizations, and other stakeholders. What GAO Found HBCUs, stakeholders, and planning documents identified extensive and diverse capital project needs. Almost all HBCUs responding to GAO's survey (70 of 79) reported that, on average, 46 percent of their building space needed to be repaired or replaced. For example, of the 35 public HBCUs that responded to GAO's survey on building condition, 8 reported more than three-quarters of their building space is in need of repair or replacement. Like all institutions of higher education, HBCUs are facing increasing capital project needs due to aging campus facilities, according to higher education organization officials and facilities experts. HBCUs primarily rely on a few sources of funding to address capital project needs, such as state grants and appropriations for public HBCUs and private giving and tuition and fees for private HBCUs. gao_GAO-17-794: Why GAO Did This Study TSA is responsible for ensuring that all passengers and property transported by commercial passenger aircraft to, from, or within the United States are adequately screened. gao_GAO-18-337: Why GAO Did This Study NASA relies on IT to support its mission, including acquiring, storing, retrieving, and analyzing information. Specifically, NASA's IT strategic planning process is not yet fully documented and its IT strategic plan lacks key elements called for by leading practices. NASA has taken steps to improve its IT strategic plan, but the updated plan is not comprehensive in that it does not fully address all four elements of a comprehensive and effective plan. NASA has also not fully implemented a workforce planning process consistent with leading practices. Specifically, NASA has not yet fully implemented a workforce planning process consistent with leading practices. Specifically, NASA has not yet fully established an IT governance structure consistent with leading practices. gao_GAO-18-72: Why GAO Did This Study The ISC requires agencies to assess physical security at federal facilities. gao_GAO-18-216: Why GAO Did This Study Counterfeit goods pose a lucrative market for criminal activity and pose risks to consumers. GAO was asked to review the market for counterfeit goods. This report examines (1) what is known about counterfeit goods entering the United States and the challenges they present, (2) efforts CBP and ICE have undertaken to enhance IPR enforcement and the extent to which they have assessed the results of these efforts, and (3) the extent to which CBP and ICE collaborate on IPR enforcement as well as ways in which they coordinate with the private sector in enforcing IPR. GAO reviewed U.S. government reports and strategic plans, analyzed CBP and ICE data, and interviewed agency officials and representatives of rights-holding companies and e-commerce websites. What GAO Found According to U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) and U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), the market for counterfeit goods in the United States has shifted from a secondary market, such as flea markets or sidewalk vendors, to a primary market, including e-commerce websites, corporate and government supply chains, and traditional retail stores, where consumers typically believe they are purchasing authentic goods. According to CBP data and ICE officials, the volume, value, and variety of counterfeit goods entering the United States increased in fiscal years 2012 through 2016, and counterfeit goods were increasingly imported in smaller express carrier or mail packages. The results of GAO's undercover purchases from third-party sellers indicate that counterfeit goods are available on a variety of popular e-commerce websites frequented by U.S. consumers. These changes in the marketplace present a number of challenges for U.S. agencies, the private sector, and consumers. First, the increasing sophistication of counterfeits can make it difficult for law enforcement officers to distinguish between legitimate and counterfeit goods. Second, the increased variety and quantity of counterfeit goods crossing the border complicates CBP and ICE enforcement efforts. Third, shifts in the mode of transportation of counterfeit goods to the United States pose additional challenges to CBP and ICE. For example, CBP and ICE have a wider variety of goods to screen, which requires CBP officials to have in-depth knowledge of a broad range of products and of how to identify counterfeits. Fourth, counterfeiters may use a variety of methods to try to deceive law enforcement or evade detection.
gao_GAO-18-253: Why GAO Did This Study DOD has taken steps to limit operational deployments for individual service members, but has been less focused on the impact of total time away from home on personnel, commonly called perstempo. Perstempo is the amount of time individual service members spend on official duty at a location or under circumstances that make it infeasible for them to spend off-duty time in the housing in which they reside. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2000 included a provision that required DOD to monitor the perstempo of the armed forces, and required DOD to manage the number of days its service members are deployed. Section 991 of title 10 defines "perstempo" as the amount of time members of the armed forces are engaged in their official duties at a location or under circumstances that make it infeasible for them to spend off-duty time in the housing in which they reside. The law also requires the Secretary of Defense or a delegated official to approve when service members exceed these thresholds, and requires DOD to establish a system for tracking and recording the number of deployment perstempo days for each member of the armed forces. In response to a mandate in the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2016, GAO was asked to review DOD's management of perstempo. This report examines (1) DOD, service, and Special Operations Command policies regarding perstempo and (2) the extent to which DOD and the services have reliable data to monitor perstempo. GAO analyzed DOD, service, and SOCOM policies and data for fiscal years 2012 through 2016 and interviewed officials from DOD, the services, and SOCOM. What GAO Found The Department of Defense (DOD), service, and Special Operations Command policies vary in identifying specific and measurable thresholds on perstempo for individual service members. DOD policy focuses on time away for deployment, which is a part of perstempo but does not encompass the full range of activities that can take service members away from home. Specifically, a 2013 memorandum from the Under Secretary of Defense for Personnel and Readiness states that individual service members should not be deployed longer than they are at their home station. However, the memorandum describes perstempo only in general terms—stating that individual service members should not serve extended periods of time away from their homestation unless required

gao_GAO-18-155: Why GAO Did This Study The biodefense enterprise is a complex set of interagency efforts to protect the nation from threats posed by biological agents. The federal government has a broad range of roles and responsibilities for biodefense, including assessing the threat of biological threats and coordinating efforts across the biodefense enterprise. GAO was asked to review the biodefense enterprise. This report examines (1) how key federal agencies use threat awareness information to inform biodefense investments and (2) the extent to which key federal agencies share biological threat information and develop a biodefense strategy. GAO reviewed relevant federal laws, policies, and guidance; analyzed agency documents and interviewed officials from key federal agencies; and reviewed relevant federal laws, policies, and guidance. What GAO Found Key federal agencies use threat awareness information to better understand threats and help make biodefense investments. For example, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the Department of Defense (DOD) use threat awareness information to identify biological threat agents of concern and broad-based capability needs, which help guide their biodefense investments. For example, HHS and USDA conduct global disease surveillance to identify and characterize naturally occurring disease events that may impact human, animal, and plant health. In addition, the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) conduct research to characterize naturally occurring diseases and pests and pathogens. Agencies also use threat awareness information to help prioritize their investments across various biodefense enterprise activities, such as assessing the potential of biological agents to cause catastrophic harm. Multiple mechanisms exist to share biological threat information, and a new biodefense strategy could help agencies better use threat information to leverage resources across the biodefense enterprise. Officials from key federal agencies, including DHS, DOD, HHS, and USDA, identified multiple mechanisms that facilitated collaboration and shared threat awareness. These mechanisms often serve multiple purposes, such as developing policy and aiding in information sharing. However, opportunities remain to enhance threat awareness across the entire biodefense enterprise, leverage shared resources, and inform budgetary tradeoffs among various threats and agency programs. For example, the National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) for Fiscal Year 2017 required DOD, HHS, DHS, and USDA to jointly develop a national biodefense strategy and associated implementation plan. The law requires the strategy to be submitted to Congress not later than 275 days after enactment (September 2017)

gao_GAO-18-493: Why GAO Did This Study DOD has spent billions of dollars developing and acquiring space systems in the past decade. DOD has been considering new architectures and acquisition approaches to increase resiliency. DOD has used commercially hosted payloads to achieve cost savings and on-orbit capability more quickly. GAO was asked to review DOD's use of commercially hosted payloads. This report examines (1) the extent to which DOD has used commercially hosted payloads and (2) the factors contributing to DOD's limited use of these payloads. GAO reviewed DOD and other documents and interviewed officials from DOD, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, and other government agencies. What GAO Found Since 2009, the Department of Defense (DOD) has used commercially hosted payloads—intended to test or demonstrate an on-orbit capability—for three programs on commercial host satellites. DOD estimates that it has achieved cost savings of several hundred million dollars from these experimental payloads. DOD officials told GAO that experimental payloads tend to be smaller, less expensive, and their missions more risk-tolerant than traditional operational DOD payloads. In these ways, they said experimental payloads are better-suited to hosting arrangements than operational DOD payloads. DOD and Air Force officials told GAO they are planning to pursue commercially hosted payloads for three programs in the coming decade to achieve cost savings and on-orbit capability more quickly. Two factors have contributed to DOD's limited use of commercially hosted payloads. First, DOD officials identified logistical challenges to matching government payloads with any given commercial host satellite. For example, most of the offices GAO spoke with cited size, weight, and power constraints, among others, as barriers to using hosted payloads. Second, while individual DOD offices have realized cost and schedule benefits, DOD as a whole has limited information on costs and benefits of hosted payloads. Further, the knowledge it has gathered is fragmented across the agency—with multiple offices collecting piecemeal information on the use of hosted payloads. The limited knowledge and data on hosted payloads that is fragmented across the agency has contributed to resistance among space acquisition officials to adopting this approach.

gao_GAO-19-134T: Why GAO Did This Study FCC and RUS are the primary sources of federal funding to deploy broadband infrastructure in rural and remote areas where the cost of providing service is high, including tribal lands. FCC's 2010 National Broadband Plan stated that tribes needed substantially greater financial support than was available to them at the time and that accelerating tribal broadband deployment would require increased funding. GAO was asked to review FCC's efforts to increase broadband deployment on tribal lands. This statement discusses (1) FCC's data on broadband access on tribal lands and (2) the extent to which tribes have access to federal funding for broadband deployment on tribal lands. This statement is based on GAO's September 2018 report on broadband access on tribal lands and selected updates conducted in September 2018. GAO reviewed FCC's National Broadband Plan and RUS's funding data for broadband deployment on tribal lands and interviewed FCC and RUS officials and representatives from tribes, broadband providers, and associations. What GAO Found In its September 2018 report on broadband access on tribal lands, GAO found that the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) collects broadband availability data from broadband providers, but its method for collecting the data does not accurately or completely capture broadband access—the ability to obtain service—on tribal lands. Specifically, FCC directs fixed broadband providers to submit a list of census blocks where service is available on their Form 477 filings. FCC defines “available” as whether the provider does—or could, within a typical service interval or without an extraordinary commitment of resources—provide service to at least one end-user premises in a census block. Thus, in its annual reports and maps of fixed broadband service, FCC considers an entire block to be served if a provider reports that it does, or could offer, service to at least one household in the census block. FCC's definition of availability leads to overstatements of fixed broadband availability on tribal lands by: (1) counting an entire census block as served if only one location has broadband, and (2) allowing providers to report availability in blocks where they do not have any infrastructure connecting homes to their networks if the providers determine they could offer service to at least one household. FCC has noted that overstatements of availability can be particularly problematic in rural areas, where census blocks cover larger areas. gao_GAO-19-141: Why GAO Did This Study Medicare pays long-term care hospitals (LTCH) for care provided to Medicare beneficiaries. Two qualifying hospitals—Craig Hospital and Shepherd Center—are among the most common LTCHs in the United States. GAO was asked to review Medicare payments to these two hospitals. This report examines (1) the extent to which Medicare payments to the two qualifying hospitals are consistent with Medicare payment policies, and (2) similarities and differences between the two hospitals and other facilities that treat Medicare patients with spinal cord and brain injuries. GAO analyzed Medicare claims data and other information from fiscal year 2013 through fiscal year 2016, and interviewed officials from CMS and the Medicare Payment Advisory Commission (MedPAC), among others. GAO also reviewed Medicare claims data and other information from CMS and the Medicare Payment Advisory Commission. What GAO Found GAO found that most Medicare beneficiaries at the two qualifying hospitals need specialized services to manage the chronic, long-term effects of a catastrophic spinal cord or brain injury. Most of these patients are younger than 65 and ineligible for Medicare at the time of their initial injury, according to officials from the qualifying hospitals. Instead, according to officials, these patients typically become eligible for Medicare 2 years or more after their initial injury due to disability. The two qualifying hospitals—Craig Hospital and Shepherd Center—received payments at the standard rate, which is a lower rate than the average comparable acute care rate for all Medicare discharges. However, GAO found that the two hospitals would receive some payments at the standard rate, but that most of their discharges would be paid at the lower, site-neutral rate—assuming similar caseloads (e.g., patient mix). In addition, officials from both qualifying hospitals and some stakeholders GAO interviewed noted that payment policies may result in fewer services provided and fewer patients served by the qualifying hospitals and other LTCHs. For example, officials from Craig Hospital told GAO they stopped providing post-operative care to patients requiring spinal surgery, such as patients with syringomyelia, in 2016—instead referring them to other facilities—in part because these discharges do not meet the criteria for the standard rate. As of September 2018, they do not plan to provide this care in the future unless the temporary exception is extended. The two qualifying hospitals treat patients with different conditions than most of those treated at other LTCHs, and treat fewer Medicare beneficiaries.

gao_GAO-18-107: Why GAO Did This Study SIV holders are special immigrants who have worked for the U.S. government in Iraq or Afghanistan and are treated like refugees for purposes of federal public assistance, including receipt of resettlement assistance. GAO was asked to review SIV holders' experiences in the United States. This report examines (1) the extent to which SIV holders have experienced short-term outcomes and long-term outcomes, (2) the challenges SIV holders face in resettling in the United States, and (3) the extent to which ORR has provided targeted assistance to SIV holders. GAO analyzed data from the Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration (PRM) for fiscal years 2011 through 2017 and interviewed officials from national and local resettlement agencies, advocacy groups, and other stakeholders. GAO also conducted 11 focus groups with SIV holders in four states selected based on geographic diversity and other factors. What GAO Found Limited data from PRM from fiscal year 2011 through part of fiscal year 2017 showed that most principal special immigrant visa (SIV) holders were unemployed and relied on cash assistance for income 90 days after arrival to the United States. The most recent data from one of its programs, the Matching Grant program, showed that most SIV holders were employed 6 months after arrival and no longer reliant on cash assistance. Although ORR regularly surveys the general refugee population up to 5 years after resettlement in order to examine their longer-term outcomes, it has never surveyed SIV holders for such information. SIV holders faced a variety of challenges while resettling in the United States, according to representatives of 13 local resettlement agencies GAO interviewed and SIV holders who participated in 11 focus groups. Among local resettlement agencies, the two in Northern Virginia reported significant challenges with their capacity to assist the large numbers of SIV holders in the area, while agencies in other locations GAO visited reported fewer capacity challenges. SIV holders also experienced challenges finding skilled employment, which did not align with their expectations of resettlement in the United States. Additionally, securing affordable and suitable housing, and female spouses' assimilation to U.S. culture were reported challenges. Officials GAO interviewed from some resettlement agencies reported taking steps to address some of these issues.
gao_GAO-18-643: Why GAO Did This Study WMATA is the nation's largest transit system, with ridership of more than 1 million passengers per weekday. WMATA's workforce is composed of bus and rail operations staff, as well as managers, administrators, law enforcement, and others. GAO was asked to review WMATA's workforce costs. This report assesses (1) how WMATA's workforce costs have changed from fiscal years 2006 through 2017 and factors contributing to those changes; (2) how WMATA identifies and addresses its current and future workforce needs; and (3) how WMATA has designed, implemented, and monitored its employee performance management systems. GAO analyzed WMATA's budget and annual audited financial statements from fiscal years 2006 through 2017, and interviewed WMATA officials and union leaders. What GAO Found The Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority's (WMATA) total workforce costs—composed of wages, salaries, and benefits for current and retired employees—increased modestly in inflation-adjusted fiscal year 2017 dollars, with wages and salaries increasing an average 1.1 percent per year, from $645 million in 2006 to $728 million in 2017. These costs grew at a slower rate than the costs of contracted services (7.3 percent annually on average) and employee and retiree benefits (5.6 percent annually on average). WMATA officials attributed these increases to several factors, including increasing ridership and the cost of providing paratransit service. WMATA's pension plans, due to their relative size and maturity and investment decisions, pose a particular risk to WMATA's financial operations: Relative size and maturity: WMATA's pension plans are large relative to its business operations, and the size of the plans' participants poses a combined financial risk to WMATA. WMATA officials told GAO that WMATA has not fully assessed the risks of its pension plans to the agency's financial operations. Without a comprehensive assessment of these risks, WMATA and its stakeholders—such as its Board of Directors—are limited in their ability to prepare for economic scenarios that could ultimately increase the amount WMATA is required to contribute to its pension plans. WMATA identifies the staffing levels it needs each year through its annual budgeting process, but does not have a strategic process to identify and address its long-term workforce needs to meet the agency's goals.

gao_GAO-18-467: Why GAO Did This Study DOD is responsible for acquiring goods and services, including weapons systems, and has a demanding role in delivering these goods and services. DOD has proposed reducing the time it takes to award contracts in order to address concerns that it is taking too long. GAO was asked to evaluate the length of time taken to award contracts. This report examines (1) DOD's efforts to determine the time it takes to award weapon systems contracts; (2) what available data show regarding the time between solicitation issuance and award for selected weapon systems-related contracts; and (3) factors identified as contributing to contract award time frames. GAO analyzed DOD contract data for a nongeneralizable sample of 129 weapon systems-related contracts, surveyed DOD contracting officials for 60 of these contracts, and interviewed DOD officials and industry representatives. What GAO Found The Department of Defense (DOD) components in GAO's review have efforts underway to track and reduce the time to award contracts, but these efforts are not coordinated across the department. DOD components collect information on the time to award contracts, but differ on what information they collect and how they use it. DOD is taking a number of actions to understand the information the components collect such as determining what events are tracked, but DOD does not have a department-wide strategy for collecting and assessing the components' information. DOD officials stated that they are starting to identify events common across the components, relative to contract award time frames. Based on GAO's analysis, 88 of the 129 contracts were awarded less than a year from the solicitation issuance date, while 38 were awarded between 1 and 2 years. gao_GAO-18-575: Why GAO Did This Study North American energy markets are extensively integrated, and the United States is the largest and fourth largest foreign supplier of crude oil to the United States. The United States is also the largest buyer of petroleum products refined in the United States. Mexico is also a major buyer of petroleum products refined in the United States. U.S. agencies have a role in energy integration efforts. GAO was asked to review U.S. energy integration efforts. This report examines (1) ways in which the U.S., Canadian, and Mexican governments cooperate on North American energy integration; (2) U.S. agencies' activities to facilitate North American energy integration; (3) U.S. agencies' efforts to coordinate among themselves on North American energy integration; (4) ways in which U.S. agencies obtain feedback and input from U.S. industry and civil society regarding North American energy integration; and (5) steps that U.S., Canadian, and Mexican officials suggested to further facilitate North American energy integration. GAO reviewed documents and interviewed officials from the Departments of Energy (DOE), the Interior (Interior), Commerce (Commerce), State (State), Transportation (DOT), and the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC), and the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID). GAO also surveyed U.S. agencies' energy integration activities implemented from 2014 through 2017. What GAO Found U.S., Canadian, and Mexican governments cooperate on energy integration, although some strategic efforts have made limited progress. At the presidential level, trilateral cooperation has occurred mainly through the North American Leaders' Summit, where the leaders of the three countries discuss economic issues, including energy, according to U.S. government officials. The last summit was in 2016, and as of April 2018 a future summit had not been scheduled. At the agency level, U.S. officials and their counterparts in Mexico and Canada cooperate technically to address specific issues related to North American energy integration. U.S. agencies reported 81 activities related to North American energy integration from 2014 through 2017, according to agency officials. Some of these activities had multiple purposes or goals, such as technical discussions and assistance, regulatory cooperation, international agreements and other instruments, trade promotion, and research and development. For example, DOE and Interior have cooperated on energy efficiency standards and have developed a framework for energy integration. DOT has engaged in a number of energy-related trade missions to Mexico and Canada.

gao_GAO-19-48: Why GAO Did This Study The nation's pipeline system is a vital component of the nation's energy infrastructure. gao_GAO-19-76: Why GAO Did This Study DOT has the authority to enforce consumer protections for airline passengers. gao_GAO-19-124: Why GAO Did This Study Congress has enacted restrictions on the use of certain appropriated funds to promote the sale or export of U.S. tobacco and tobacco products since the 1990s. These restrictions have been enacted through annual appropriations acts through fiscal year 2018. GAO was asked to review the restrictions on promoting tobacco exports. This report examines (1) the guidance select U.S. agencies have issued to implement funding restrictions on promoting tobacco exports overseas, (2) to what extent overseas officials from select U.S. agencies were aware of the restrictions and guidance, and (3) to what extent select U.S. agencies have implemented this guidance overseas. GAO reviewed U.S. appropriations laws that prohibited the funds appropriated therein from being used to promote the sale or export of U.S. tobacco or tobacco products since the 1990s, and guidance issued by State, Commerce, and USDA. GAO also interviewed officials in headquarters from State, Commerce, and USDA about post officials' implementation of guidance regarding the restrictions and guidance, and the types of questions they receive from post officials about the restrictions and guidance. GAO also reviewed agency documents and interviewed officials in headquarters from State, Commerce, and USDA about post officials' implementation of guidance regarding the restrictions and guidance. What GAO Found The Departments of State (State), Commerce (Commerce), and Agriculture (USDA) collaborate with each other to develop and periodically issue an interagency guidance cable to implement funding restrictions on promoting tobacco. According to officials, this cable serves as the primary source of guidance for implementing the restrictions on promoting tobacco. State has updated and issued the cable four times since 2013 to address changes in tobacco technology and other emerging issues, according to officials at these agencies. Commerce relies on both the interagency guidance cable and its client eligibility policy to implement restrictions on promoting tobacco. USDA relies on the interagency guidance cable to provide direction to its officials overseas, and does not have agency-specific guidance for implementing its permanent funding restrictions on promoting tobacco. USDA officials said that the cable sufficiently addresses the restrictions on the agency's promotion activities and helps to ensure that all officials serving at posts overseas conduct activities in a consistent manner. Most State, Commerce, and USDA officials overseas GAO interviewed were aware of the restrictions on promoting tobacco. Most officials GAO interviewed had received some guidance concerning the restrictions, but several officials did not recall receiving the interagency guidance cable.

gao_GAO-18-303: Why GAO Did This Study In fiscal year 2016, FWS awarded $1.5 billion in grants, which was about 50 percent of the agency's total $2.9 billion budget authority. GAO reviewed relevant federal laws and regulations, agency guidance, and documents and interviewed agency officials. gao_GAO-18-610: Why GAO Did This Study The Great Lakes-Seaway is a key transportation link between U.S. manufacturing, agricultural, and other industries in the nation's interior to the global economy. gao_GAO-18-57: Why GAO Did This Study FAA is responsible for regulating the commercial space launch industry, which includes unmanned and manned vehicles and from the United States and overseas. FAA requires launch companies to purchase a MPL, which is intended to reflect the greatest dollar amount of loss to third parties and the federal government for bodily injury and property damage that can be reasonably expected from a launch or reentry accident. The Commercial Space Launch Act Amendments of 1988 established the foundation for the current U.S. policy to potentially provide federal payment for a portion of claims by third parties for injury, damage, or loss that results from a launch or reentry accident. GAO was asked to review FAA's MPL methodology. This report examines the extent to which FAA (1) evaluated its MPL methodology incorporating three requirements, (2) addressed previously identified weaknesses, and (3) updated its MPL methodology. GAO reviewed FAA's MPL methodology and interviewed agency officials. GAO also reviewed FAA's MPL methodology and interviewed launch providers and insurance companies. What GAO Found The Commercial Space Launch Act Amendments of 1988 required the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) to evaluate its MPL methodology incorporating three requirements, but the agency's report did not fully address these requirements. First, the act required FAA to ensure a balance of risk between launch companies and the federal government. However, agency officials told GAO that they did not re-evaluate the probability thresholds—which are used to divide the risk of loss between launch companies and the federal government—as part of evaluating its MPL methodology when implementing the risk profile method due to resource constraints. Second, the act required FAA to consider the cost impact of implementing an updated MPL methodology, but the agency did not evaluate the impact of implementing its revised methodology on the direct costs to launch companies and to the federal government. Third, the act required FAA to consult with the commercial space sector and insurance providers in evaluating its MPL methodology, but they did not consult such parties in response to the act. Without fully addressing CSLCA's mandated requirements, FAA cannot ensure that the federal government is not exposed to greater liability costs than intended or that launch companies are not required to purchase more insurance coverage than necessary. gao_GAO-18-163: Why GAO Did This Study The federal government provides about $1.3 billion in federal student aid each year to help borrowers avoid default on their loans. The CDR is intended to hold schools accountable for borrowers who default within the first 3 years of repayment. GAO was asked to review the CDR. gao_GAO-18-254: Why GAO Did This Study Fintech firms are nontraditional providers of financial products and services that are offered to consumers. Fintech firms are not subject to routine federal oversight, but they may be subject to state oversight and enforcement. GAO was asked to review fintech. GAO also reviewed relevant federal laws and regulations and interviewed regulators and market participants. What GAO Found Fintech products can provide consumers and the broader financial system with various benefits, but may also pose risks similar to those of traditional products. Fintech products can provide consumers with greater convenience, lower cost, increased financial inclusion, faster services, and improved security. For example, consumers can use fintech products and services on their mobile devices to make payments; transfer money; easily obtain payment for shared expenses; obtain loans; or receive investment advice without the time and expense of visiting a financial service provider's physical location. Fintech products also pose risks similar to those of traditional products, such as fraud, discrimination, and unsuitable advice. While existing laws apply to fintech products and services in most cases, some fintech products pose additional risks that may not be sufficiently addressed by existing laws. For example, some fintech products pose additional risks that may not be sufficiently addressed by existing laws. While the legal framework for consumer protection applies to many of the risks associated with fintech products, the extent to which consumers benefit from these protections is a function of the existing regulatory framework and its coverage of fintech activity. Fintech firms' compliance with applicable consumer or other laws varied. Fintech firms that offer investment advice typically register with and are subject to examinations by federal securities regulators. Some fintech firms providing payments or loans that have partnered with federally regulated banks or credit unions may receive indirect oversight from federal financial regulators as part of their efforts to ensure that their regulated entities are adequately managing the risks of these arrangements. Nonpartnered fintech firms would not typically be subject to routine examinations by a federal financial regulator but would instead be subject to state regulatory oversight and enforcement. While fintech firms and financial institutions are subject to different degrees of routine federal oversight, GAO found that indications of fintech firms causing widespread harm were limited as they were subject to fewer complaints

What GAO Found GAO's analysis of the Veterans Health Administration's (VHA) Choice Program appointment scheduling process indicates that veterans who are time-eligible could potentially wait up to 70 calendar days to obtain care, if VA medical centers (VAMC) and TPAs take the maximum amount of time allowed by VA's process. GAO's analysis indicates that veterans who are referred to the Choice Program for routine care because they are time-eligible could potentially wait up to 70 calendar days to obtain care, if VAMCs and TPAs take the maximum amount of time allowed by VA's process. gao_GAO-18-181: Why GAO Did This Study DOD requires reservists to maintain readiness by participating regularly in training to maintain the military skills needed to perform their mission. GAO reviewed DOD's travel regulations and other documents, and interviewed officials from DOD's six reserve components. What GAO Found Reservists may incur out-of-pocket travel expenses under certain conditions in connection with their service that are not reimbursable under Department of Defense (DOD) travel regulations. Officials responsible for travel regulations and reserve policy issues told GAO that this can occur because (1) the cost to attend Inactive Duty Training is a reservist's responsibility, except in limited circumstances; and (2) DOD designates longer duration training or assignments as a Permanent Change of Station—a change in a reservist's home of record—and not as temporary travel. DOD's Joint Travel Regulations govern the extent to which reservists are eligible to be reimbursed for travel expenses to participate in required training or in other duties. The regulations authorize the reimbursement of different types of expenses depending on the nature and duration of the assignment. Eligible reimbursements include: Per diem, which includes reimbursement for food, temporary lodging, Transportation expenses, ranging from reimbursement for mileage traveled in reservists' private vehicles to reimbursement for commercial flights; Permanent Change of Station reimbursements related to reservists changing their home of record to the location of the assignment, such as reimbursement for the movement of household goods; and Basic Allowance for Housing, which is based on the costs of adequate rental properties for civilians with comparable income levels in the same location as the permanent duty station, which in the case of reservists is generally the location of their home. gao_GAO-18-418: Why GAO Did This Study IRS authenticates taxpayers to provide reasonable assurance that it is interacting with the legitimate taxpayer. This report examines, among other things, (1) the extent to which ODNI has implemented continuous evaluation across the executive branch, and (2) the extent to which executive branch agencies have established timeliness goals for completing periodic reinvestigations. What GAO Found The Office of the Director of National Intelligence (ODNI) has taken an initial step to implement continuous evaluation across the executive branch in a phased approach, but it has not yet formalized the program in policy. Specifically, in October 2016, ODNI initiated the first phase of continuous evaluation and outlined requirements for this phase in interim guidance distributed to implementing agencies in December 2016. For the first phase of implementation, executive branch agencies are to conduct certain continuous evaluation record checks against a portion of their national security population. ODNI provided agencies with prioritization guidance to help them select individuals for continuous evaluation. Nearly 80 executive branch agencies are subject to the requirements for this first phase of implementation. ODNI officials stated that they have not yet issued a government-wide policy or an expanded definition of continuous evaluation. As a result, agencies may develop inconsistent approaches to implementing continuous evaluation. ODNI has not yet determined key aspects of its continuous evaluation program, which has limited the ability of executive branch agencies to plan for implementation in accordance with ODNI's phased approach. For example, while ODNI has initiated the first phase of continuous evaluation in coordination with implementing agencies, it has not yet determined what the future phases of implementation will entail, or when they will occur. Moreover, ODNI has not set any further timeframes for implementing continuous evaluation or determined agency requirements for future phases. ODNI officials stated that because continuous evaluation is a new initiative, no realistic timeline for full implementation will be set until the initial results of implementation are analyzed and technical capabilities have matured. gao_GAO-18-450: Why GAO Did This Study The PAIMI Act provides grants to state PAIMI programs to protect and advocate for individuals with mental illness.
