GAO also reviewed SAMHSA procedures for monitoring program compliance with statutory and regulatory requirements. What GAO Found The eight selected state Protection and Advocacy for Individuals with Mental Illness (PAIMI) programs reported resolving a majority of individuals' cases related to alleged abuse, neglect, or rights violations in fiscal year 2016, and they reported concluding a variety of systemic activities, with a significant focus on monitoring and addressing issues of abuse or neglect at facilities. Through their work with individuals and completion of systemic activities, the selected programs reported meeting a majority of their priority goals and objectives. SAMHSA has controls in place for monitoring the PAIMI programs' compliance with statutory and regulatory requirements through its ongoing and periodic in-depth monitoring activities. GAO found evidence that SAMHSA had identified and resolved a variety of compliance issues through these activities. For example, SAMHSA followed up with one program in which the advisory council had failed to meet the threshold of 60 percent of its membership being individuals who have received or are receiving mental health services, or are family members of such individuals. SAMHSA also has procedures to oversee state PAIMI program compliance during its periodic onsite monitoring reviews. GAO identified two weaknesses that could be limiting SAMHSA's oversight of program effectiveness. First, SAMHSA's PAIMI program monitoring did not consistently record changes to program priority goals, objectives, and targets—collectively, "benchmarks"—made during a performance year, and the agency did not have procedures for examining such changes over time. Second, the agency did not provide timely information to programs on identified deficiencies from onsite monitoring. As of March 2018, SAMHSA was in the process of implementing new processes for its oversight of state PAIMI programs that officials believe will streamline the agency's monitoring activities. However, these changes may not fully address the weaknesses GAO identified.

gao_GAO-18-499: Why GAO Did This Study U.S. agencies implement foreign assistance programs under the auspices of government-wide strategies. GAO was asked to review U.S. foreign assistance strategies. This report examines the extent to which foreign assistance strategies address key elements that GAO identified related to alignment of agencies' efforts—specifically, elements related to (1) interagency coordination, (2) strategic integration, and (3) assessment of progress toward strategic goals. GAO reviewed 63 government-wide, agency, multi-agency, regional, sector-specific, and multi-agency strategies that were in effect during 2017. GAO also reviewed agency guidance related to foreign assistance strategies. What GAO Found Many of the 52 foreign assistance strategies that GAO reviewed at least partially addressed the key elements GAO identified related to alignment of foreign assistance strategies, but some did not address these elements. Regarding interagency coordination, 40 percent of the strategies generally identified roles and responsibilities for implementing the strategies, while 33 percent generally identified interagency coordination mechanisms; 23 percent and 38 percent, respectively, did not address these elements. Regarding strategic integration, 58 percent of the strategies GAO reviewed described linkages with U.S. foreign assistance strategies in the same sector and 54 percent generally described linkages with relevant higher- or lower-level U.S. foreign assistance strategies; 21 percent and 25 percent, respectively, did not identify such linkages. Regarding assessment of progress toward strategic goals, almost all of the strategies generally established desired results and a framework of goals and objectives and described activities to achieve results; however, 21 percent did not identify milestones or performance indicators and 21 percent did not outline plans for monitoring and evaluation. GAO also found that the six agencies implementing most U.S. foreign assistance do not have consistent guidance for strategy development that could help ensure their strategies address the key elements GAO identified. For example, State and USAID guidance for strategy development includes many of these elements but does not cover all strategies that these agencies are involved in developing. Additionally, guidance for State's and USAID's joint regional strategies, State's functional bureau strategies, and USAID's country development cooperation strategies does not apply to other State and USAID strategies, such as the joint State-USAID integrated country strategies.

gao_GAO-19-225T: Why GAO Did This Study The Navy and Marine Corps have experienced significant mishaps at sea in recent years, resulting in 17 sailors' deaths and serious damage to Navy ships. The Navy and Marine Corps have made progress identifying the causes of their readiness decline and have begun efforts to arrest and reverse it; however, GAO's prior work shows that fully addressing the persistent readiness challenges will require years of sustained management attention. This testimony addresses (1) the Navy's and Marine Corps' readiness challenges and the costs associated with expanding the fleet to enhance readiness in the future, and (2) the extent to which the Navy and Marine Corps have sustained maintenance and supply challenges that affect readiness recovery. This statement is based on GAO's prior work and updated information from November 2018 on Navy and Marine Corps readiness. GAO's work has included a review of Navy and Marine Corps data on maintenance and supply challenges, and interviews with Navy and Marine Corps officials in Japan. What GAO Found The Navy and Marine Corps face significant challenges in rebuilding the readiness of their forces and the costs associated with expanding the fleet to enhance readiness in the future are unknown. The Navy has taken steps to address training shortfalls in the surface fleet, such as establishing controls to limit waivers that allowed training lapses to worsen, and the Navy has improved markedly in the percentage of cruisers and destroyers with lapsed certifications in Japan. However, the Navy continues to struggle with rebuilding the readiness of the existing fleet due to enduring maintenance and manning challenges. As the Navy seeks to expand its fleet by 25 percent, these challenges will likely be further exacerbated and the Navy will likely face additional affordability challenges. Navy and Marine Corps aircraft availability has been limited by aging aircraft, delayed maintenance, and insufficient supply support. Pilot and maintenance personnel shortfalls further limit readiness recovery across legacy air platforms. The growing F-35 program, which is meant to replace many aging aircraft, has presented additional operational and sustainment challenges, which will likely persist into the future if not corrected. DOD, the Navy, and the Marine Corps have emphasized mission capability of critical aviation platforms—including the Navy and Marine Corps F/A-18s and F-35s—and are taking steps to improve availability, but these efforts will take time to realize results.

gao_GAO-19-180: Why GAO Did This Study FATCA was enacted in 2010 to improve visibility into taxable income from foreign sources and enhance IRS's ability to identify and pursue taxpayer noncompliance. gao_GAO-19-35: Why GAO Did This Study OPM is the government's chief human resources agency and personnel policy leader. OPM provides guidance and resources to agencies on performance management. gao_GAO-18-451T: Why GAO Did This Study The U.S. Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO) administers the CBM program, which allows parties accused of patent infringement to challenge patents that are invalid or unpatentable. The program allows parties to challenge patents that are invalid or unpatentable on a number of grounds, including subject matter eligibility, novelty, non-obviousness, and clarity and specificity. This testimony discusses (1) the extent to which patents challenged under the CBM program have been challenged and the extent to which the board has reviewed the patents and the processes that lead to them, and (2) stakeholders' views on the program's effects on innovation and investment. This statement is based on GAO's March 2018 report, Patent Trial and Appeal Board: Stakeholders Agree the CBM Program Has Reduced Litigation and Many See Value in Maintaining Aspects of the Program (GAO-2018-02-28). GAO reviewed relevant laws, regulations, and guidance; analyzed petition data from September 2012 through September 2017; and interviewed stakeholders, including patent owners, patent attorneys, and patent trial and appeal board judges. What GAO Found GAO found in its March 2018 report that, from September 2012 through September 2017, parties accused of patent infringement filed 524 petitions with the Patent Trial and Appeal Board challenging the validity of 359 distinct patents under the CBM program, resulting in rulings against about one-third of these patents. gao_GAO-18-599: Why GAO Did This Study The U.S. Census Bureau (Bureau) is responsible for counting the nation's population. The Bureau has a longstanding challenge of enumerating hard-to-count groups, such as minorities, young children, and renters. The Bureau has also been working to improve the enumeration of these groups in the 2020 Census. GAO was asked to review the Bureau's efforts to improve the enumeration of these groups. This report examines (1) the Bureau's plans to enhance its efforts to improve the enumeration of hard-to-count groups in the 2020 Census, and (2) the Bureau's internal management and external workforce challenges in improving the enumeration of these groups. GAO reviewed Bureau planning documents and interviewed Bureau officials. What GAO Found The Bureau plans to enhance its efforts to improve the enumeration of hard-to-count groups in the 2020 Census, but its estimated spending is similar to what it reported spending on those efforts in 2010 after adjusting for inflation. The Bureau plans to continue to rely on its Integrated Partnership and Communications operation—designed to communicate the importance of census participation and motivate self-response—as a key component of its efforts to improve the enumeration of hard-to-count persons in the 2020 Census. Evaluations conducted by the Bureau found that its partnership and communications efforts had positive effects on increasing awareness and participation among the hard-to-count in prior censuses. The Bureau also plans to change other key operations to help improve the enumeration of certain hard-to-count groups. For example, the Bureau overhauled a metric it has used to help manage and target field work for its partnerships to areas with hard-to-count populations, basing it now on predictions of each household's likelihood to self-respond to the census. The Bureau also plans to increase the number of non-English languages formally supported by the Bureau. The Bureau estimates total spending for its 2020 partnership and communications efforts to be similar to what it reported spending on those efforts for the 2010 Census after adjusting for inflation. Specifically, according to Bureau documents, the Bureau plans to hire nearly twice as many partnership specialists—responsible for building relationships and obtaining commitments from organizations—to support the 2020 Census than it hired to support the 2010 Census.

gao_GAO-18-436T: Why GAO Did This Study The federal government issues guidance and regulations to help regulated entities comply with agency regulations and address new issues and circumstances more quickly than may be possible using rulemaking. Agencies considered a number of factors before deciding whether to issue guidance or undertake rulemaking. GAO found opportunities for agencies to improve regulatory guidance processes by strengthening compliance with OMB requirements for significant guidance and the use of management controls for producing their guidance documents. These actions would help to ensure appropriate review and use of these documents

Whether these programs changed their requirements is unclear. gao_GAO-18-520T: Why GAO Did This Study DHS is responsible for improving and promoting the cybersecurity of federal and private-sector networks. DHS has broad authorities to improve and promote cybersecurity of federal and private-sector networks. The Federal Information Security Modernization Act of 2014 clarified and expanded DHS's responsibilities for assisting with the implementation of, and overseeing, information security at federal agencies. The act also requires DHS to assess its cybersecurity workforce. This testimony is based on GAO's ongoing work on DHS's cybersecurity efforts. It addresses the extent to which DHS (1) has implemented its cybersecurity authorities and responsibilities, (2) has taken actions to identify its cybersecurity workforce, and (3) has taken actions to identify its cybersecurity critical needs. GAO reviewed relevant federal laws and policies, and interviewed DHS officials. What GAO Found The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) has broad authorities to improve and promote cybersecurity of federal and private-sector networks. The federal laws and policies that underpin these authorities include the Federal Information Security Modernization Act of 2014, which clarified and expanded DHS's responsibilities for assisting with the implementation of, and overseeing, information security at federal agencies. These responsibilities include requirements to: develop, issue, and oversee agencies' implementation of binding operational directives to agencies, including directives for incident reporting, contents of annual agency reports, and other operational requirements; monitor agencies' implementation of information security policies provide operational and technical assistance to agencies, including by operating the federal information security incident center, deploying technology to continuously diagnose and mitigate threats, and conducting threat and vulnerability assessments of systems. The Cybersecurity Protection Act of 2015 codified the role of the National Cybersecurity and Communications Integration Center (NCCIC)—a center established by DHS in 2009—as the federal civilian interface for sharing information concerning cybersecurity risks, incidents, analysis, and warnings to federal and non-federal entities, including owners and operators of information systems supporting critical infrastructure. The act also requires DHS to improve intrusion detection and prevention capabilities, as appropriate, by regularly deploying new technologies and modifying existing technologies. DHS has made important progress in implementing these programs and activities. However, the department needs to take additional actions to ensure that it successfully mitigates cybersecurity risks on federal and private-sector computer systems and networks. DHS is responsible for operating its National Cybersecurity Protection System (NCPS), operationally known as EIN

gao_GAO-18-367T: Why GAO Did This Study PTC is a new technology that is intended to prevent train-to-train collisions, derailments due to excessive speed, incursions into work zone limits, and the movement of a train through a switch left in the wrong position. gao_GAO-18-565: Why GAO Did This Study The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) required the establishment of health insurance exchanges to provide consumers with access to health insurance. The exchanges are the federally facilitated exchanges that allow consumers to compare health insurance plans and select from a variety of plans. The exchanges are also the primary source of financial assistance for enrollees. The PPACA also required GAO to report on the program's enrollment. This report examines (1) the extent to which enrollment in 2018 was affected by factors other than plan affordability, and (2) the extent to which HHS's funding for the exchanges was used to promote enrollment. GAO reviewed relevant laws, regulations, and guidance; interviewed officials from HHS, the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), and other stakeholders; and reviewed relevant federal laws and regulations. What GAO Found About 8.7 million consumers enrolled in health insurance exchanges during the open enrollment period for 2018 coverage, 5 percent less than the 9.2 million who enrolled for 2017. This decline continues a trend from 2016, when a peak of 9.6 million consumers enrolled in such plans. Since that peak, enrollment has decreased by 9 percent. Enrollment in plans sold by state-based exchanges that use their own enrollment website has remained relatively stable during the same time period, with just over 3.0 million enrollees each year since 2016. Stakeholders GAO interviewed reported that plan affordability likely played a major role in 2018 exchange enrollment—both attracting and detracting from enrollment—and enrollees' plan selection. gao_GAO-18-44: Why GAO Did This Study Opioid use disorders are a serious public health concern. gao_GAO-18-161T: Why GAO Did This Study NASA uses RPS to power its missions, including its Mars 2020 and New Frontiers missions. RPS are long-lived sources of spacecraft electrical power and heating that are rugged, compact, highly reliable, and relatively insensitive to radiation and other effects of the space environment. NASA's Science and Development Portfolio includes a wide array of missions that seek to address a variety of scientific objectives and answer many questions about the solar system, from how life began to how the solar system is evolving. In 2011, DOE established a Supply Project to produce Pu-238, a long-lived heat source that can convert heat given off by Pu-238 into about 120 watts of electrical power at the beginning of its life. This testimony is based on GAO's September 2017 report, NASA: Challenges to Reach Full Production Goals (GAO-17-322). This testimony is based on GAO's September 2017 report, which examined (1) NASA's use of RPS and Pu-238, and (2) DOE's progress in meeting NASA's demand for Pu-238 to fuel RPS. GAO reviewed NASA and DOE planning documents and interviewed officials from DOE, NASA, and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA). What GAO Found NASA selects radioisotope thermoelectric system (RPS) for missions primarily based on scientific objectives and mission destinations. NASA officials GAO interviewed stated that mission selections were influenced by the limited amount of available Pu-238. However, several other factors may affect NASA's demand for RPS and Pu-238: Costs associated with missions that typically require RPS. According to NASA officials, RPS have typically been used on Flagship missions that cost $2 billion or more. NASA can support no more than one mission using RPS about every 4 years—or two to three missions per decade—based on expected agency funding levels. Technological advances may reduce the demand for Pu-238 and thus RPS. For example, advances in solar power technology have realistically expanded the ability to use solar power for missions for which it would not have been considered before, and these advances could help address low levels of light intensity for deep space missions. NASA also is developing new RPS technologies that may reduce its demand for Pu-238 and thus RPS. DOE has made progress meeting NASA's future demand for Pu-238 to fuel RPS.

gao_GAO-19-226: Why GAO Did This Study Indian students are a growing population in the United States, and many of these students attend public schools. Indian students attend schools in areas with large numbers of Indian students. GAO was asked to review Indian students' access to public schools. This report examines the public school choice options located in areas with large populations of Indian students, collectively referred to as Indian students. GAO analyzed Education data for school year 2015-16 (the most recent available), analyzed Education data from the 100 school districts with the largest number of Indian students, and interviewed federal officials and academic subject matter experts. What GAO Found Few areas with large numbers of Indian students had options other than traditional public schools, according to GAO's analysis of Education data for school year 2015-16. Of the 451 school districts with high percentages of Indian students in GAO's analysis, 84 percent (378 districts) had only traditional public schools. The remaining 16 percent (73 districts) had at least one charter school, charter school, magnet school, or career and technical education school. The most common option was a Bureau of Indian Education (BIE) school. Among districts that had only traditional public schools, about three-quarters of them had more than one school. There are several reasons why there may be few public school options in districts with high percentages of Indian students. For example, nearly all of these districts are located in rural areas. Experts said there are often not enough students in rural areas to justify adding schools beyond the traditional public schools or BIE schools that already exist, and rural school districts can face challenges recruiting and retaining qualified teachers. In the 100 school districts with the largest number of Indian students, 75 percent of the schools were concentrated in 15 school districts. Indian students enrolled in charter schools in similar percentages as non-Indian students. In the remaining districts, enrollment patterns varied. For example, in one district near Boise, Idaho and another near Fairbanks, Alaska, Indian students attended charter schools at higher percentages than their peers by 60 percentage points and 6 percentage points, respectively. In the remaining districts, Indian students enrolled in magnet schools at lower percentages than non-Indian students. Whether Indian students enrolled in different types of schools could be a function of local differences in school choice and could be influenced by the extent to which these schools offered curricula that reflect Indian languages, cultures, or histories. gao_GAO-18-230: Why GAO Did This Study DOD has spent over $1.3 billion since 1990 to support its forces. DOD's excess capacity analysis is intended to provide Congress with information on the amount of excess capacity within DOD. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2016 included a provision for GAO to review DOD's 2017 excess capacity analysis. This report examines the extent to which DOD's 2017 report addressed or partially addressed the required elements. GAO reviewed DOD's 2017 report and interviewed DOD officials. What GAO Found The Department of Defense's (DOD) 2017 excess capacity analysis has limitations that affect the accuracy and analytical sufficiency of the estimate. Specifically, DOD's use of a 1989 baseline for excess capacity results in inaccurate estimates of excess capacity; DOD's methodology included assumptions that were not always reasonable; and DOD's approach to estimating excess capacity is not always sufficient or implemented consistently across the military departments. DOD recognizes the limitations of its analysis, specifically noting that the resulting percentages of excess capacity are at best indicators to justify the more detailed analysis of excess capacity provided by a full base realignment and closure (BRAC) round. Specifically, DOD used a baseline for the analysis that did not fully take into account changes in infrastructure needs since 1989, used assumptions in its analysis that are not reasonable, and used methods that were not sufficient or implemented consistently. These limitations resulted in excess capacity estimates that do not have the accuracy and analytical sufficiency to support decision making on future BRAC rounds. Without improvements to DOD's method of estimating excess capacity, DOD is not providing the information that Congress requires to make decisions concerning the management of excess infrastructure capacity within the department. Similarly, DOD does not have the information it needs to appropriately manage its infrastructure capacity and therefore cannot make informed decisions about what it needs to support its mission as land and infrastructure requirements of newer weapon systems are introduced. Moreover, the combined effect of neither DOD nor Congress having the information means that DOD will continue to experience challenges with funding related to its infrastructure and potential excess costs.

gao_GAO-18-100: Why GAO Did This Study In 2016, Medicare spent about $380 billion on health care services for beneficiaries enrolled in Medicare FFS, which consists of two separate parts: Medicare Part A, which primarily covers hospital services, and Medicare Part B, which primarily covers outpatient services. The majority of the 38 million Medicare FFS beneficiaries were enrolled in both Part A and Part B, although about 5 million were enrolled in Part A only and 0.3 million were enrolled in Part B only. The current Medicare FFS cost-sharing design leaves beneficiaries exposed to potentially catastrophic cost-sharing, and in part because of that, in 2015, 81 percent of Medicare FFS beneficiaries obtained supplemental insurance that covered some or all of their Medicare cost-sharing responsibilities, often in exchange for an additional premium. GAO was asked to review the design of Medicare FFS cost-sharing. This report examines (1) the extent to which Medicare FFS cost-sharing can be confusing, contribute to beneficiaries' overuse of services, and leave beneficiaries exposed to catastrophic costs, and (2) the effect of implementing a modernized design on beneficiaries' cost-sharing responsibilities. GAO analyzed relevant literature and interviewed officials from CMS, the Medicare Payment Advisory Commission, and others. GAO also reviewed four illustrative cost-sharing designs that GAO analyzed and interviewed experts. What GAO Found The current Medicare fee-for-service (FFS) cost-sharing design can be confusing, contribute to beneficiaries' overuse of services, and leave beneficiaries exposed to catastrophic costs. Modernizing the design could address these concerns, but would involve trade-offs. For example, maintaining Medicare's share of costs would involve a trade-off between the level of the cap and the deductible (or other cost-sharing). The direct effect of modernizing the Medicare FFS cost-sharing design (i.e., the effect when holding utilization and enrollment constant) on beneficiaries' cost-sharing responsibilities would depend on specific revisions and the time horizon examined. For example, if the design had a cap near $10,000, the median annual cost-sharing responsibility would be $479, which is below that of the current design ($621), despite the addition of a cap. In contrast, designs with relatively low caps—and therefore greater beneficiary protection from catastrophic costs—would result in a median annual beneficiary cost-sharing responsibility above that of the current design. gao_GAO-18-28: Why GAO Did This Study NASA is integrating and assessing the programmatic and technical readiness of the three programs—SLS, Orion, and EGS—into a system to launch humans to Mars. What GAO Found The National Aeronautics and Space Administration's (NASA) approach for integrating and assessing the programmatic and technical readiness of its current human spaceflight programs, executed by the Exploration Systems Development (ESD), differs from prior NASA human spaceflight programs. ESD manages both the programmatic and technical cross-program integration, and primarily relies on personnel within each program to implement its integration efforts. Additionally, the approach creates an environment of competing interests because it relies on dual- hatted staff to manage technical and safety aspects on behalf of ESD while also serving as independent oversight of those same areas. ESD has made progress reducing risks over the past 2 years, but key integration risk areas remain for the integration effort. For example, delays with the European Service Module—which will provide services to the Orion crew capsule—could affect the Orion program's schedule. gao_GAO-18-30: Why GAO Did This Study FEMA's Public Assistance (PA) program is a multibillion dollar program that provides grants to states and localities to help them rebuild and recover from disasters. GAO reviewed FEMA's 2014 PA Program Realignment report and other program documents, and interviewed program officials and stakeholders. What GAO Found The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) designed the new PA delivery model to respond to persistent workforce management challenges related to identifying the required number of staff and needed skills and training, among other things, to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the PA preaward process. gao_GAO-18-518: Why GAO Did This Study FSA is responsible for administering the federal student aid program, which provides loans, grants, and work-study funds to students attending college or career school. FSA shares PII with non-school partners, such as loan servicers, guaranty agencies, and private collection agencies, to assist them in carrying out their functions. GAO was asked to review FSA's oversight of non-school partners' protection of student aid data. This report (1) describes the roles of FSA's non-school partners in the federal student financial aid program, including the types of personally identifiable information shared with them; and (2) assesses the extent to which FSA's policies and procedures for overseeing non-school partners' protection of federal student aid data align with federal requirements, federal guidance, and best practices. GAO reviewed FSA documents and interviewed FSA officials. What GAO Found The Office of Federal Student Aid's (FSA) non-school partners play key roles in the federal student financial aid program, particularly with regard to the servicing, repayment, and collection of student loans. These partners include loan servicers, guaranty agencies, and private collection agencies. FSA shares PII with these partners to assist them in carrying out their functions. FSA has established policies and procedures for overseeing its non-school partners' protection of the personally identifiable information that it shares with the partners. These policies and procedures vary in the extent to which they address the key practices for overseeing the protection of PII. For example, FSA's policies and procedures for Title IV loan servicers and private collection agencies fully address three of the four key practices that pertain to loan servicers and private collection agencies. However, FSA's procedures for guaranty agencies do not require monitoring controls on an ongoing basis. Finally, for FFEL lenders, FSA has minimal oversight procedures. FSA's limited oversight could result in inconsistent or ineffective implementation of security controls, which in turn could have serious consequences for the privacy of millions of borrowers whose information is shared with non-school partners.

gao_GAO-18-349T: Why GAO Did This Study The Veterans Appeals Improvement and Modernization Act of 2017 (the Act) required VA to develop a comprehensive plan for implementing the new and legacy disability appeals processes. This statement is based on GAO's March 2017 report, Veterans Appeals Improvement and Modernization: VA's Appeals Plan Against Required Elements (GAO-17-92). GAO reviewed VA's appeals plan and supplemental materials, and interviewed VA officials. What GAO Found The Veterans Appeals Improvement and Modernization Act of 2017 (the Act) requires the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to develop a comprehensive plan for implementing the new and legacy disability appeals processes. VA's appeals plan addresses 17 of the Act's 22 required elements, partially addresses 4 related to monitoring implementation and workforce planning, and does not address 1 element related to identifying total resources. For example, VA's appeals plan addresses the required elements related to, among other things, identifying legal authorities for hiring and removing employees, estimating timeliness for hiring and training employees, and outlining the outreach VA expects to conduct. However, VA's appeals plan does not address all 22 of the Act's required elements. For example, VA's appeals plan does not articulate a set of goals and measures that cover all aspects of its new appeals process, such as accuracy of decisions and cost. VA's appeals plan also does not articulate how it will monitor processing of legacy appeals and how it will track both sets of workloads. VA's appeals plan reflects certain aspects of sound planning practices related to managing the implementation of process change; however, other key components are not addressed.
